Charles Wankel's profile is located at http://facpub.stjohns.edu/~wankelc

{{cuisine|Malta}} | [[Cookbook:European cuisines|European cuisines]] {{Wikipedia|Maltese cuisine}}
Malta's typically Mediterranean cuisine reflect its history as well as its geography and is the result of the relationships between the Islanders and the many foreign dominations over the centuries. The distinctive traditional island dishes are based on the produce of the land and sea, and some of these reflect gastronomically the legacies of the past with elements of Arab, Spanish and Southern Italian influences as well as of the more recent British colonial presence (1800 to 1964). Sweets in particular show influences from the Arab period that started in 869 A.D. (the Arabs conquered Sicily in 827 A.D). It is not surprising that Malta and Sicily have a few dishes in common (or call them counterparts or relatives) since even after the Arab period ended Malta continued to be ruled from Sicily as one among many Sicilian islands: by the Normans first (from around 1090 when they created the Kingdom of the South), then by the enlightened Swabians (until 1250), followed briefly by the Anjouins and then the Aragonese, from 1288 until 1530, when the Maltese islands were given to the Knights of Saint John of Jerusalem (or Knights of Malta) by Charles V.
The influences from outside Malta's shores continue, though nowadays they come through travel and TV rather than foreign domination, and alongside Malta's traditional cuisine with its strong Southern Mediterranean character, there is today an eclectic mix of dishes drawn from other cuisines, not only Italian but also Asian, North American and Mexican for example. This article on Maltese cuisine however refers exclusively to the traditional dishes of Malta and Gozo, still widely prepared and enjoyed on the islands of Malta and Gozo, the second island, which boasts a number of dishes all of its own.
== Characteristics ==
== Ingredients ==
It is a simple and healthy [["Cucina Povera" ]] that makes nourishing and tasty dishes based on local vegetables, legumes and cereals. In the past it relied on pulses, eggs and local cheese for protein most of the time, though there were also meat and fish dishes for the better off anf for special occasions.
For reasons of climate and territory, Maltese Cuisine uses similar ingredients to the cuisines of the [[ Cookbook: cuisine of the Mediterranean | Southern Mediterranean Cuisines ]] using vegetables like artichokes, cauliflowers, carrots and cabbages in winter and in summer sweet peppers, zucchini, green beans, tomatoes, garlic, and onions. Fresh locally grown fruit ranges from excellent winter citrus, especially blood oranges and tangerines, to plums, peaches, melons, watermelons, grapes, figs, mulberries, prickly pears and pomegranates. Fish and shellfish are plentiful and include delicacies like sea urchin and the ever-popular squid and octopus dishes. The most popular meats are pork and rabbit, chicken and kid; game birds like quail and woodcock are still popular unlike horsemeat and sea turtle meat, which were traditionally eaten. Locally picked wild capers are notably good and a particular delicacy. They are often used in sauces especially for pasta or fish dishes. Local land snails are also popular, especially in late summer.
== Relationship with other cuisines ==
A shared history, as well as geographical proximity leading to trading and other contact, means Maltese cuisine shares some dishes with Southern Italy and with the rest of the Mediterranean. For example the Ricotta filled Sweet Cannoli are identical to those of nearby Sicily while the savoury ricotta-filled pastry snack Pastizzi resemble in shape and in the pastry used the sweet ricotta-filled Sfogliatelle of Naples. In similar fashion Malta's Baked Pastas, Pasta with Aubergines, Pasta with Tuna, with Tomato and Ricotta etc have many relatives in Calabria, Puglia, Molise, Basilicata, Campania, Sardinia and Sicily. Maltese cooked summer vegetable salads such a Caponata (a dish of Arab origins) and Peperonata are also found with local variations all round the Mediterranean, not only in Italy but also in France, Spain and Greece.
Sweets and pastries show many traces of the Arab contribution to Malta's cuisines as they are often based on nuts, dates, figs, carobs, orange flower water and Malta's superb honey. As Malta was ruled from Sicily from the Arab period until the arrival of the Knights, it is likely that sweets and sweetmeats also found in Southern Sicily had a single origin.
The British influence on Maltese cuisine is related to the importation of many products from Britain and its other colonies; for example New Zealand lamb and British cheddar cheese. Where once the Christmas meal consisted of broth or Timpana followed by a stuffed capon or a large rooster or perhaps a roast leg of pork or mutton, ending with Treacle Rings, in the last decades of British rule roast stuffed turkey and Plum Pudding became established as the Maltese Christmas meal. Tea is widely drunk on the islands and long grain rice is the kind most often used in Maltese cooking. The British also gave Malta sweets like Hot Cross Buns, Bread and Butter pudding and Rice pudding as well as a fondness for curry powder. A hint of curry powder is often detectable in meat stews and in the filling of the Bragjoli beef rolls, where the name of the dish is derived from Sicilian dialect. Potatoes - which grow locally - are served with main courses, far more often than in neighbouring Italy. Bread is often buttered, in part because this fitted in with local use of butter (made from the cream of sheep's or goat's milk) or lard rather than olive oil as the main cooking fats. And it is chips with everything on many restaurant menus - a pity as Malta's own baked potato dish like potatoes "smothered" with onions or sliced and baked in water and oil topped with caraway seeds, are far tastier.
== A Maltese Meal ==
A Maltese meal may be a one course affair or it may start with a soup.
There are many substantial soups, stews, pies and baked pastas that constitute a complete meal all by themselves. These are more likely to be cold weather fare while simply cooked fish and fresh or cooked vegetable salads like Kapunata are common in summer
Typically Maltese is the custom of cooking a meat or stuffed vegetable in soup or sauce: the soup, or the sauce served on pasta becomes the first course, while the meat or stuffed vegetable becomes the second course.
At a Maltese traditional family meal, dessert consists of fresh fruit. Cakes were reserved for holidays, Saint's Day Feasts and special occasions such as marriages and christenings.
Maltese Bread is a very important element of the diet and is ever present on the local table along with water and often wine.
== Some key features of Maltese cuisine == *a love of garlic, in fact the basis of many stews, soups and sauces is garlic, onion and concentrated tomato paste *many stuffed vegetables dishes baked, poached in broth, pan simmered; also stuffed meat and fish *healthy soups of all kinds (often made with cereals and legumes as well as vegetables, meat and fish) *one pot stews of vegetables, poultry, meat, salt cod, octopus, squid etc *many shallow fried patties of vegetables, fish, salt cod, ground pork, ground beef etc *herbs like marjoram, mint, basil in summer, thyme, parsley and bay in winter *spices like cinnamon, cloves, anise and fennel seeds, caraway and coriander *sweets scented with tangerine, orange and lemon zest and with orange flower water *the particular type of ground black pepper used in Malta has a very distinctive aroma all its own
<s></s>
== Recipes == Following is a list, by no means exhaustive, of some of the better known Maltese dishes, divided into general categories.
=== Soup === * [[Cookbook:Aljotta|Aljotta ]] Fish soup with tomato,garlic, mint or marjoram and rice * [[Cookbook:Brodu|Brodu ]] Broth * [[Cookbook:Brodu tac-Canga|Brodu tac-Canga]] Beef broth * [[Cookbook:Kawlata|Kawlata ]] Hearty chunky soup, almost a stew, of cabbage, potato and pork knuckle (or Maltese sausage), sometimes also bacon: tasty and comforting one pot winter meal * [[Cookbook:Kusksu|Kusksu ]] Spring soup of fresh Broad Beans with onions, tomatoes and mint and the essential ingredient of a typically Maltese small "bead" shaped pasta * [[Cookbook:Minestra (Malta)|Minestra ]] Thick many vegetable soup finished with grated (dry) or sliced (fresh) local cheeselets that may be related to [[Cookbook: Basque cuisine | Basque Menestra]] * [[Cookbook:Soppa ta' l-Armla|Soppa ta' l-Armla]] Widow's soup - vegetable soup topped with a sheep's milk cheeselet or a just set egg
=== Pasta and Rice === * [[Cookbook:Mqarrun il-Forn|Mqarrun il-Forn ]] Baked macaroni in tomato and minced meat sauce enriched with chicken livers, bacon, egg, diced cheese and sometimes peas * [[Cookbook:Ravjul|Ravjul]] Half moon shape home made pasta pockets with a ricotta and parsley filling, sometimes filled with fresh local sheep's cheese, dressed with a garlicky fresh tomato sauce and topped with grated cheese: either Parmigiano or a pepper corn studded Romano-like cheese known locally as "cheese for grating" * [[Cookbook:Ross il-Forn|Ross il-Forn]] Savoury rice tossed with tomato sauce, minced beef and grated cheese, bound with eggs and oven baked till firm but moist * [[Cookbook:Spaghetti biz-Zalza tal-Qarnit|Spaghetti biz-Zalza tal-Qarnit]] Spaghetti with a tomato stewed octopus sauce containing black olives, peas, tomatoes, wine, orange or lemon zest and mint or marjoram * [[Cookbook:Tarja bil-Bajd|Tarja bil-Bajd ]] Cooked Angel hair (very thin) noodles mixed with eggs, Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese and parsley and fried into a kind of crisp savoury cake * [[Cookbook:Timpana|Timpana]] Pastry enclosed or pastry topped baked macaroni as described above
=== Meat=== * [[Cookbook:Bragjoli|Bragjoli]] Small Beef roll-ups or parcels enclosing a savoury filling of breadcrumbs, parsley, bacon or ham and cheese, with a touch of curry powder often cooked in a sauce * [[Cookbook:Falda tal-Majjal Mimlija|Falda tal-Majjal Mimlija]] Pork flank stuffed with a savoury mix of grated cheese, minced pork and parsley. May be steamed, poached in broth or oven baked * [[Cookbook:Fenek Moqli|Fenek Moqli]] Jointed rabbit shallow fried with garlic * [[Cookbook:Fenek bit-Tewm u l-Inbid|Fenek bit-Tewm u l-Inbid ]] Red wine marinated rabbit on the bone simmered with garlic, bay leaves and wine * [[Cookbook:Pulpetti tal-laham |Pulpetti tal-laham]] Small meat patties of ground beef or pork mixed with breadcrumbs, grated cheese, parsley, onion and garlic *[[Cookbook:Majjal Fgat|Majjal Fgat]] "Smothered" Pork : a chunk of pork leg seasoned with salt, pepper and coriander seeds, long simmered in a tightly sealed pot. A mix of breadcrumbs, parsley, thyme, minced garlic, lemon zest and lemon juice may be added either from the start or towards the end of cooking time. * [[Cookbook:Gamiem bil Haxxu |Gamiem bil Haxxu]] Turtle doves simmered til tender with onions, potatoes, carrots and kohlrabi, then filled with pork sausage meat and finished on onions and diced bacon with red wine and optional peas. * [[Cookbook:Zalzett tal-Malti|Zalzett tal-Malti]] Maltese pork sausage with coriander seed, sea salt and black pepper, fresh or dried
=== Poultry and Game=== * [[Cookbook:Tigiega bil Haxu|Tigiega bil Haxu]] (Minced beef or rice stuffed chicken, sometimes cooked in broth/brodu)
=== Fish & Seafood === * [[Cookbook:Accjola|Accjola (Amber jack)]] * [[Cookbook:Cerna|Cerna (Grouper)]] * [[Cookbook:Denci|Denci ( Dentix - a kind of bream) ]] * [[Cookbook:Dott|Dott (Stone bass)]] * [[Cookbook:Fanfri|Fanfri (Pilot fish)]] * [[Cookbook:Lampuka|Lampuka (Mahi Mahi (Dorado)]] * [[Cookbook:Lampuki Moqlija|Lampuki Moqlija (Maltese fried dorado)]] * [[Cookbook:Pixxispad|Pixxispad (Swordfish)]] * [[Cookbook:Qarnit|Qarnit (Octopus)]] * [[Cookbook:Sargu|Sargu (White bream)]] * [[Cookbook:Spinotta|Spinotta (Sea bass)]] * [[Cookbook:Trill|Trill (Red mullet)]]
=== Pies === * [[Cookbook:Torta tal-Brungiel u l-Ikkapuljat |Torta tal-Brungiel u l-Ikkapuljat]] Aubergine and minced beef pie * [[Cookbook:Torta tal-Fenek|Torta tal-Fenek]] Rabbit pie * [[Cookbook:Torta tal-Irkotta|Torta tal-Irkotta]] Sheep's milk ricotta, parsley and cheese pie, bound with eggs * [[Cookbook:Torta tal-Laham|Torta tal-Laham]] Meat pie * [[Cookbook:Torta tal-Lampuki|Torta tal-Lampuki]] [[w:Mahi mahi|Lampuki fish]] pie with spinach, peas, capers, anchovies, walnuts and raisins,or sometimes with olives, cauliflower, spinach, chestnuts and tomato paste * [[Cookbook:Torta tal-Qargha Hamra|Torta tal-Qargha Hamra]] Savoury Pumpkin pie with rice, anchovy, black olives and tuna ideally salted not in oil * [[Cookbook:Torta tal-Qastan|Torta tal-Qastan]] Sweet pie of chestnut puree with sultanas, cocoa, cinnamon and cloves
=== Stews === * [[Cookbook:Stuffat tac-Canga|Stuffat tac-Canga]] Beef stew * [[Cookbook:Stuffat tal-Fenek|Stuffat tal-Fenek]] Rabbit slow simmered in red wine or tomato sauce * [[Cookbook:Stuffat tal-Majjal|Stuffat tal-Majjal]] Slow stewed pork * [[Cookbook:Stuffat tal-Qaqocc|Stuffat tal-Qaqocc]] A spring dish of fresh artichokes braised with fresh peas and fava beans and tomatoes, often topped with a fresh cheeselet and finished with a poached egg nestling in a hollow among the vegetables * [[Cookbook:Stuffat tal-Qarnit|Stuffat tal-Qarnit]] Octopus slow simmered in red wine with olives,tomatoes, black pepper and mint; sometimes also peas, lemon or orange zest and a hint of curry powder
=== Vegetables === * [[Cookbook:Bigilla|Bigilla]] Bean paste made from dried broad beans, garlic, parsley and olive oil, may be spiced up with the addition of a small hot pepper * [[Cookbook:Brungiel Mimli|Brungiel Mimli]] Baked aubergine (eggplant) shells filled with a mixture of minced beef, aubergine/eggplant, cheese, tomato, garlic and parsley, with a crisp cheese and breadcrumb topping * [[Cookbook:Bzar Ahdar Mimli|Bzar Ahdar Mimli]] Stuffed green peppers - many fillings exist: minced beef, rice, fresh Lampuka, canned tuna. May be cooked on top of the stove or baked * [[Cookbook:Kapunata|Kapunata]] Cold cooked summer vegetable medley of aubergines, sweet bell peppers, tomatoes, garlic, summer herbs and olive oil * [[Cookbook:Qaqocc Mimli|Qaqocc Mimli]] Globe artichokes stuffed with breadcrumbs, parsley and garlic * [[Cookbook:Qargha Baghli Mimli|Qargha Baghli Mimli]] Stuffed baby marrows - pale green round courgettes (zucchini)
=== Pastry === * [[Cookbook:Imqaret|Imqaret]] Deep fried pastry diamonds with an Anis scented date paste filling * [[Cookbook:Kannoli|Kannoli]] Ricotta filled crisp deep fried pastry tubes * [[Cookbook:Pastizzi|Pastizzi]] Savoury small crisp pastry pie filled with ricotta or split peas * [[Cookbook:Qassatat|Qassatat]] Savoury small round pie with ricotta, split peas or other fillings * [[Cookbook:Qassatat tal-Incova|Qassatat tal-Incova]] Small round savoury pies with spinach and anchovy filling, optional slivers of black olive and cooked split green peas
=== Eggs and Cheese === * [[Cookbook:Froga|Froga]] Maltese style omelette * [[Cookbook:Barbuljata|Barbuljata ]]Malta style barely set scrambled eggs with tomato, garlic and mint or parsley * [[Cookbook:Gbejna|Gbejna]] Artisan goat or sheep's milk [[w:Gbejniet|cheeselets]] * [[Cookbook:Gbejna friska or Gnejna tal-ilma)|Gbejna Friska]] The fresh soft version, sweet creamy milk taste * [[Cookbook:Gbejna Mahsula|Gbejna mahsula]] Salt cured in brine (a salt and water mix) * [[Cookbook:Gbejna Moxxa|Gbejna moxxa]] Aged dried Gbejna * [[Cookbook:Gbejna tal-Bzar|Gbejna tal-Bzar]] The sharper and harder textured pepper cured version. These may also be preserved by pickling in a mixture of oil and vinegar, when they develop a piquant flavour and a crumbly texture
=== Bread === * [[Cookbook:Galletti|Galletti]] Round hard Maltese [[w:hardtack|Sea biscuits]] * [[Cookbook:Hobza tal-Malti|Hobza tal-Malti]] Maltese crusty durum wheat sour dough bread * [[Cookbook:Hobz biz-Zejt|Hobz biz-Zejt ]] Maltese olive oil and tomato based sandwich, a portable lunch
=== Snacks === * [[Cookbook:Bebbux|Bebbux (Land snails)]] * [[Cookbook:Arjoli|Ajjoli (Garlic sauce for snails)]]
=== Sweets === * [[Cookbook:Biskutelli|Biskutelli]] Dry crisp anis scented toasted biscuit for dipping in milk, tea, or coffee * [[Cookbook:Biskuttini tal-Lewz|Biskuttini tal-Lewz]] Almond macaroons * [[Cookbook:Figolli|Figolla]] Maltese Easter sweet in various shapes with an almond paste filling, decorated with glazed designs * [[Cookbook:Helwa tat-Tork|Helwa tat-Tork]] Sesame Paste Halva with whole almonds and/or pistachios * [[Cookbook:Krustini|Krustini]] Country hard biscuits for sipping in tea or coffee * [[Cookbook:Kwarezimal|Kwarezimal]] Lent sweet with almonds, cinnamon and the zest of lemon, orange and tangerine, perfumed with orange blossom water, topped with chopped pistachios and drizzled with honey * [[Cookbook:Pudina tal-Hobz|Pudina tal-Hobz]] Crisp topped tender bread pudding with cocoa and sultanas and sometimes chopped dates, glacé cherries, chopped almonds, orange zest * [[Cookbook:Ottu tal-Gunglien|Ottu tal-Gunglien]] Figure of eight soft buns sprinkled with sesame seeds * [[Cookbook:Qaghaq tal-Ghasel|Qaghaq tal-Ghasel]] Semolina, candied citrus peel and treacle filled pastry rings * [[Cookbook:Qubbajt|Qubbajt]] Nougat soft or hard, with almonds, hazelnuts or all sesame seed * [[Cookbook:Torta Tat-Tamala|Torta tat-Tamal]] Date pie with cocoa, chopped walnuts, Anisette liqueur, orange juice and zest
=== Beverages === * [[Cookbook:Imbuljuta|Imbuljuta]] Chestnut and tangerine Christmas drink * [[Cookbook:Ruġġata|Ruġġata]] Refreshing summer long drink made from almonds * [[Cookbook:Kafé misjur |Kafé misjur]] Coffee flavoured with chicory, cinnamon, cloves and anis * [[Cookbook:Rożolin |Rożolin ]] A fruit based sweet liquer (many fruits may be used)
[[Category:Maltese recipes|*]]

{{recipe}}
== Ingredients == * 6 eggs * 2 potatoes (medium) * 1 bunch of spring onions / scallions * cheddar cheese * handful of parsley chopped fine * salt and pepper * 100g cooked lean beef chopped very small and fine.(optional)
== Variation on Beef == * 200g Corned beef
== Procedure == # Boil potatoes then mash them. Chop the Spring Onions(scallions) and grate the cheese. # Place the mashed potatoes in a bowl and add the spring onions, beef, cheese, the parsley and salt and pepper, mix together then add the eggs and mix everything together. # Heat some oil in a frying pan. # Add 3 large spoonfuls of the mixture to the frying pan flatten out to around 1 cm thickness so you are cooking 3 smaller froga (omelettes). # Cook until golden brown. # Serve with salad and fresh buttered bread.

revision.comment: New page: {{subst:joinus}} Also, writing an image to a file without viewing it can be done using "imwrite", eg: >>imwrite(imagename, 'filename.extension'). Don't forget the extension or it won't...
revision.text:
{{#ifeq:"{{NAMESPACE}}"|"User talk"| Hello and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]], a collection of open-content textbooks! You should really consider [[Special:Userlogin|creating an account or login in]]. Here are some advantages: * The use of a username of your choice. * Greater security and privacy, your IP address will be hidden from most users. * You get your own personal user page and talk page, instead of having to share it. * [[Special:Contributions/{{PAGENAME}}|Your contributions]] will be recognized as your own, and not confused with anyone elses. * The use of your own watchlist which shows when pages you are interested in have changed. * Your opinions carry greater weight in the [[Wikibooks:Decision making|decision making process]]. * You become a recognized member of the Wikibooks community. * Creating an account is easy and only takes a few minutes of your time. We hope that you choose to become a [[Wikibooks:Wikibookians|Wikibookian]] and [[Special:Userlogin|create an account]].
Feel free to ask any questions on my talk page or in the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading room]].
Be sure to sign your posts and comments on talk pages with four tildes (~~~~), this will let other editors know you said it.
|
'''This template must only be used on User talk pages.'''
}} Also, writing an image to a file without viewing it can be done using "imwrite", eg: >>imwrite(imagename, 'filename.extension'). Don't forget the extension or it won't work. I don't have time now but sometime later I'll try and put some of that stuff in its own section. Or you can do it if you want :). Regardless, have a good day. [[User:Mattb112885|Mattb112885]] ([[User talk:Mattb112885|talk to me]]) 14:58, 22 November 2007 (UTC)

{{recipesummary|Breakfast recipes|10|prep 30 minutes (while oven preheating)
cook 45 minutes
1½ hours total|3|image=[[File:Finished sausage breakfast casserole.jpg|300px]]}} {{recipe}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of the United States|American cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Breakfast|Breakfast cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Sausage|sausage]] | [[Cookbook:Cheese|cheese]] | [[Cookbook:Meat|meats]] | [[Cookbook:Bread Recipes|bread recipes]] ==Ingredients== * 2 [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] (8-[[Cookbook:Ounce|ounce]] package) shredded [[Cookbook:Cheddar Cheese|cheddar cheese]] * 8 large [[Cookbook:Egg|eggs]], [[Cookbook:Beat|beaten]] * ¼ [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Garlic|garlic]] powder * 2 [[Cookbook:Green Onion|green onions]], tops only, sliced * 24 ounces evaporated [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] (or substitute 3 cups of milk) * ½ teaspoon [[Cookbook:Onion|onion]] powder * 1 teaspoon dry mustard * ½ cup [[Cookbook:Chop|chopped]] [[Cookbook:Red Pepper|red pepper]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Pound|pound]] hot bulk [[Cookbook:Pork|pork]] [[Cookbook:Sausage|sausage]], cooked, drained, and crumbled * 8 cups (8 to 10 slices) ½ inch cubed [[Cookbook:French Bread|French]] or [[Cookbook:Italian Bread|Italian]] [[Cookbook:Bread|bread]] - ideally a day old or a little stiff ==Procedure== # Preheat [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to {{#invoke:temperature|f|350}}. # (Cook, drain, and crumble sausage.) # Grease a 9 by 13 inch [[Cookbook:Pots and Pans|baking pan]]. # Place bread cubes in the pan evenly. # Combine eggs, garlic powder, green onion tops, evaporated milk, onion powder, and mustard. # Pour into baking dish. # Crumble sausage over the mixture evenly. # Add cheese and peppers, if desired, over the top. # If preparing ahead, cover and refrigerate. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] until set, about 45 minutes. Sausage Breakfast Casserole.jpg|Sausage Breakfast Casserole, before baking, in a 13x9 casserole pan. Finished sausage breakfast casserole.jpg|Finished sausage breakfast casserole ==Tips, Notes, and Variations== * Serve warm. * May also be referred to as [[Cookbook:Sausage tossage|Sausage tossage]]. [[Category:Inexpensive recipes|Sausage Casserole, Wakeup]] [[Category:American recipes|Sausage Casserole, Wakeup]] [[Category:Breakfast recipes|Sausage Casserole, Wakeup]] [[Category:Casserole recipes|Sausage Casserole, Wakeup]] [[Category:Cheese recipes|Sausage Casserole, Wakeup]] [[Category:Egg recipes|Sausage Casserole, Wakeup]] [[Category:Pork recipes|Sausage Casserole, Wakeup]]

revision.comment: ...just don't eat this with pasta (bread with bread??)
revision.text:
{{recipesummary|Bread recipes|2 loaves|3-3½ hours|3}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of Italy|Italian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|vegetarian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Holiday Recipes|holiday recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Bread Recipes|bread recipes]]
=Italian Bread=
===Ingredients===
* 1 package [[Cookbook:Yeast|active dry yeast]] * 1⅓ [[Cookbook:Cup|cups]] warm [[Cookbook:Water|water]] (about 110°F) * 1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] [[Cookbook:Vegetable oil|vegetable oil]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 1 tablespoon [[Cookbook:Sugar|sugar]] * 3½ to 4 cups [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * ½ cup wheat germ, optional * 1 teaspoon [[Cookbook:Cornstarch|cornstarch]] dissolved in ⅓ cup water
===Directions===
# In a large bowl, sprinkle yeast over warm water and let stand for 5 minutes. # Stir in oil, salt, and sugar. # Add 2½ cups flour and mix to blend. # Using a spoon or heavy duty [[Cookbook:Mixer|mixer]], [[Cookbook:Beat|beat]] until elastic, about 5 minutes. # Stir in (you may want to use [[Cookbook:Dough Hook|dough hooks]]) another cup of flour and wheat germ, if desired to make a stiff dough. # Knead on a board or pastry cloth, floured with some of the last ½ cup flour, until dough is springy and smooth and develops small bubbles just under the surface (about 20 to 25 minutes-you may want to do this with the dough hooks). # Put in greased bowl, turning to grease top, then cover with a cloth. # Rise until doubled, about an hour, depending on temperature. # Punch down dough, turn out, and divide in half. # Preheat [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|375°F]]. # Shape each half of dough into a slender oval loaf about 15 [[Cookbook:Inch|inches]] long. # Place on greased [[Cookbook:Cookie Sheet|baking sheet]], cover lightly and let rise until nearly doubled, about 30 to 40 minutes. # Bring cornstarch mixture to a [[Cookbook:Boil|boil]] and stir until thick and clear. # Brush loaves with mixture. # Slash loaf tops ½ inch with floured sharp knife or razor blade. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] until loaves browned and sound hollow when tapped, 25 to 30 minutes. # Cool on [[Cookbook:Wire Rack|wire racks]].
===Tips, Notes, and Variations===
* A cup of whole wheat flour may be substituted for a cup of plain flour. * To get a rapid initial rise, use water about 130-135°F, and pour into bowl with '''yeast mixed with initial flour and salt and sugar''' and start mixing. * All rising should be in a warm place, like near the refrigerator. * A baking stone, ceramic brick, or even an iron skillet or griddle preheated in the oven (to place the the baking sheet on) will give a good "spring" or quick rise when the loaves are first placed in the oven.
===Uses===
* Great with cheese and cold meats on a picnic.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Italian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Baked recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegan recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipesummary|Bread recipes|2 loaves|3-4 hours|3}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of France|French cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|vegetarian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Holiday Recipes|holiday recipes]] | [[Cookbook:Bread Recipes|bread recipes]]
=Easy French Bread=
==Ingredients==
* 2 packages [[Cookbook:Yeast|active dry yeast]] * ¼ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] warm [[Cookbook:Water|water]] (about 110°F) * 2 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoons]] [[Cookbook:Butter|butter]] or [[Cookbook:Margarine|margarine]] * 2 cups warm [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Teaspoon|teaspoon]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 7½ to 8 cups [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]]
==Procedure==
# In a large bowl, sprinkle yeast over warm water and let stand for 5 minutes. # Stir in butter, milk, and salt. # Start adding flour and mix until dough is thick and pulls off spoon like gum. # Knead until dough is springy and smooth (about 10 minutes-you may want to do this with dough hooks). # Form into a ball and put in greased bowl, turning to grease top, then cover with a cloth. # Rise until doubled (until a finger impression stays), about an hour, depending on temperature. # Punch down dough, turn out, and divide in half. # Preheat [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to [[Cookbook:Oven temperatures|425°F]] (220°C). # Shape each half of dough into a square. # Roll dough into two 10 by 15-[[Cookbook:Inch|inch]] (25 x 35 cm) oblongs; roll up each, starting on the long side. # Place each oblong on a greased [[Cookbook:Cookie Sheet|baking sheet]] sprinkled with [[Cookbook:Cornmeal|corn meal]]. # Slash loaf tops ¼ inch (almost 1cm) diagonally with floured sharp knife or razor blade. # Brush loaves with water. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] 10 minutes, then reduce heat to 375°F (190°C). # Brush loaves with water again. # Bake another 10 minutes. # Brush loaves with water again. # Bake another 10 to 15 minutes, until golden brown. # Cool on [[Cookbook:Wire Rack|wire racks]].
==Tips, Notes, and Variations==
* To get a rapid initial rise, use water about 130-135°F (55-60°C), and pour into bowl with '''yeast mixed with initial flour and salt''' and start mixing. * All rising should be in a warm place, like near the refrigerator. * A baking stone, ceramic brick, or even an iron skillet or griddle preheated in the oven (to place the the baking sheet on) will give a good "spring" or quick rise when the loaves are first placed in the oven.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|French Bread, Easy]] [[Category:French recipes|Bread, Easy French]] [[Category:Baked recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bread recipes|French Bread, Easy]] [[Category:Milk recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

page.title: Wikibooks:Requests for deletion/Teaching Assistant in France Survival Guide/Directory

revision.text:
== [[Teaching Assistant in France Survival Guide/Directory]] == {| cellspacing="5" cellpadding="5" style="border: 1px red solid; background: #ffffcc; width: 95%; margin: auto; color: #000000;" | style="width: 40px; text-align: center;" | [[Image:Stop hand.svg|30px]] | Closed as '''delete'''. This page lists and encourages the addition of people who are teaching assistances in France, rather then a list of contributors/editors. While it may be valuable, included in a book and can be updated, it isn't educational, instructional and/or verifiable. Most of the contributors to this page are anonymous users. This information is better hosted somewhere else, such as perhaps Wikia, a blog, a personal homepage or a social networking website, and perhaps included as an external resource. However the relevancy of a list for finding a teaching assistance in France in a book intended to help teaching assistance in France may be questionable as well. --[[User:Darklama|dark]][[User_talk:Darklama|lama]] 00:57, 4 November 2007 (UTC) Closed as delete ?!?! I don't agree one bit about your rational and the outcome you selected to enforce, most of it would apply to a book but not to a page of one book, this actions alienates people and in this case people that are our target for contributions (teachers)... --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] 18:07, 9 November 2007 (UTC) I've requested for an undelete... --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] 18:32, 9 November 2007 (UTC) I have to agree. I know policy says that it's the weight of the votes and not the quantity that counts but ignoring peoples votes just alienates people from the project. I've added my vote to the undelete request also. [[User:Xania|Xania]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 23:11, 10 November 2007 (UTC) :Making a decision based on the weight/quality of the reasons is not the same as ignoring people's votes. I wasn't ignoring people's votes. I don't see the point in discussing this in two places or in assuming bad faith was involved. If you disagree with my decision just vote for undeletion on the [[WB:VFU#Teaching Assistant in France Survival Guide/Directory|undeletion page]] and explain your reasons in a civil manner. --[[User:Darklama|dark]][[User_talk:Darklama|lama]] 23:29, 10 November 2007 (UTC) |- | colspan="2" style="border-top: 1px red dashed;" | Actually seems to be up-to-date, but I wonder if we want it at all. ''' – [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 16:56, 28 August 2007 (UTC) *'''Comment'''. This one has been nominated for VfD before. We should look through the archives first and figure out what was the outcome of the previous discussion before we try to delete it again. That's not to say that because it was kept before that it must be kept now, but instead that if there is a precident, that we should take that into consideration. --'''Whiteknight''' ([[User:Whiteknight|Page]]) ([[User talk:Whiteknight|Talk]]) 21:35, 28 August 2007 (UTC) **{{comment}} - I don't think it was. I looked in the archives and couldn't find anything. I also scrolled through the entire edit history, and I didn't see anything that looked like it had been nominated previously. If I'm wrong, please point me in the right direction. Regardless, we can still consider the question now. ''' – [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 19:42, 1 September 2007 (UTC) ***You're probably right. I feel like the issue has come up before, but I guess it hasnt. maybe i'm thinking of something else. --'''Whiteknight''' ([[User:Whiteknight|Page]]) ([[User talk:Whiteknight|Talk]]) 23:11, 3 September 2007 (UTC) I cannot see why this has been nominated for deletion. Can someone please explain further? —Preceding [[w:Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[User:Keishazown|Keishazown]] ([[User talk:Keishazown|discuss]] • [[Special:Contributions/Keishazown|contribs]]) :[[WB:WIW|Wikibooks is not a web directory]]. Refer to the discussion concerning [[Wikibooks:Requests for deletion/Movie making directory]] and [[Wikibooks:Requests for deletion/Freeware]]. Nevertheless, the community may decide that this is an acceptable appendix to the textbook. I don't think it is, but we go by community consensus. ''' – [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 12:43, 5 September 2007 (UTC) *'''Delete''' the page concerned contains personal (& unverifiable) information some of which is likely out of date. It is not what Foundation projects are intended for --[[User:Herbythyme|Herby]] [[User talk:Herbythyme|talk thyme]] 12:41, 5 September 2007 (UTC) *'''Keep''' - This is more an appendix to [[Teaching Assistant in France Survival Guide]], although I would normally suggest that pages like this is better left for Wikia rather than something on Wikimedia projects. The parent page... the survival guide... has been nominated in the past for deletion, so I do think this is a different situation. [[WB:WIW#Wikibooks is not paper]] also applies here in this case, and I should note that this directory is meaningless outside of the context of being associated with the survival guide. Even so, the survival guide does not strictly need this directory in order to exist, even though there is some additional value added if only to indicate how many people are actually reading and using the survival guide. I might like to add some warning messages about the potential for spammers to abuse lists of this nature and to encourage the use of the internal Wikibooks (MediaWiki) e-mail functions to discourage spammers, but that is a personal choice.

I do agree as a general rule that web directories should not be encouraged on Wikibooks, but a little more latitude ought to be given to appendicies as long as it is subject-related. I have seen similar lists of readers/editors on other Wikimedia projects, even if the are in a different context. --[[User:Robert Horning|Rob Horning]] 15:29, 15 September 2007 (UTC) *{{keep}}. It doesn't seem to be advertising or out of date, as long as both of these are true I don't see a problem with it. [[User:Mattb112885|Mattb112885]] ([[User talk:Mattb112885|talk to me]]) 03:10, 16 September 2007 (UTC) *{{keep}} Looks like a potentially useful page. [[User:Xania|Xania]] [[Image:Flag_of_Italy.svg|15px]][[User talk:Xania|talk]] 23:38, 16 September 2007 (UTC) *{{Vd}} Even were the information verifiable (which as herby points out, it is not), this is still a directory of people's names and contact information. Directories, as the policy that mike quoted above says, are not textbooks and do not belong here. It would be akin to people who program in C posting their names and email addresses in the C book, or people who speak english posting that information into the rhetoric book. The fact is that a directory by itself isnt a textbook, and a directory of people doesnt belong inside a textbook either. It's just not useful instructional material, even if it does have some other sort of value. Remember that Wikibooks is not for the accumulation of all random "valuable" information, but that we are for the creation of textbooks (however loosely we choose to define that word). --'''Whiteknight''' ([[User:Whiteknight|Page]]) ([[User talk:Whiteknight|Talk]]) 16:46, 20 September 2007 (UTC) *'''Keep''' - If the page was the hole book then I would agree with the delete by in the context of the book it is indeed part of it. Probably a notice about posting personal data (as emails) should be added to the page. --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] 17:13, 22 September 2007 (UTC) |}

revision.comment: /* Last Copyright Warning */ modify for use here
revision.text:
{{{1|Welcome, {{PAGENAME}}!}}} {| style="background:white; border:1px solid #abd5f5;; padding:0px; border-spacing:0px;" ! style="background:#d0e5f5;" | [[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|Getting started]] with Wikibooks |- | style="padding:5px;" | * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. Find out [[WB:WIW|what this means]]. * To sign your name (on talk pages), use four tildes, like this: ~~~~ * For help in using the wiki, see [[Using Wikibooks]]. * For information about the community here, see [[Wikibooks Community]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold|be bold]], and have fun! |} Come introduce yourself at the [[WB:SLN|new users]] page. If you have any questions, you can ask there or contact me personally.'''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 19:22, 22 November 2007 (UTC) ==Wikibooks cannot accept copyrighted content== {{mbox|type=warning|msg=Hello, and [[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome to Wikibooks]]! We welcome and appreciate your contributions, such as [[:Cookbook:Aljotta‎]], but we regretfully cannot accept [[Wikibooks:Copyrights|copyrighted]] works borrowed from either websites or printed material, or works which use an unacceptable license. For more information, please read [[Wikibooks:Media]]. Thanks and Happy editing! '''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 19:22, 22 November 2007 (UTC)}} == Last Copyright Warning == {{mbox|type=warning|msg= '''Please stop adding copyrighted content.'''
All content is copyrighted and cannot be used on Wikibooks unless it is declared to be appropriately licensed, or is in the public domain. If you continue adding copyrighted content, you will be temporarily blocked from editing Wikibooks. Furthermore, any content which is discovered to be copyrighted will be deleted [[WB:DP|per policy]]. Thank You. '''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 19:22, 22 November 2007 (UTC)}}

==Welcome!== [[Help:Welcome, newcomers|Welcome to Wikibooks]], a collection of open-content textbooks! You don't have to [[Special:Userlogin|log in]] to read or edit articles on Wikibooks, but creating an account is quick, free and non-intrusive, requires no personal information, and gives you many benefits, including: *The use of a username of your choice *The ability to view all your contributions via a "My contributions" link *Your own [[wikipedia:user page|user page]] *Your own talk page which, if you choose, also allows users to send you messages without knowing your e-mail address *The use of your own personal [[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]] to which you can add articles that interest you *The ability to rename pages. *The ability to [[Special:Upload|upload images]] *The ability to customize the appearance and behavior of the website *The eligibility to become an [[Help:Administrators|administrator]] *The right to be heard in votes and elections *Your IP address will no longer be visible to other users.
We hope that you choose to become a Wikibookian and '''[[Special:Userlogin|create an account]]'''. Feel free to ask me any questions you may have on my talk page. By the way, make sure to sign your posts and comments with four tildes ('''~~~~'''), which will let others know who left it.
'''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|<font color="Indigo">Mike.lifeguard</font>]]''' | <sup>[[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|<font color="Indigo">talk</font>]]</sup> 19:41, 22 November 2007 (UTC)

{{mbox|type=notice|msg=[[User:Triceratops9|Triceratops9]]: Please log in to edit. Thanks! '''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|<font color="Indigo">Mike.lifeguard</font>]]''' | <sup>[[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|<font color="Indigo">talk</font>]]</sup> 19:46, 22 November 2007 (UTC)}}
How does it matter if I log in or not? I'll try to remeber to but I don't see how its important [[User:Triceratops9|Triceratops9]] 20:09, 22 November 2007 (UTC) :It matters if you're having conflicts (albeit minor) with another editor. Consider it a favour to me. Happy editing! revision.comment: New page: the figure of acoustic power should have a reference level for the dB scale. in air acoustics it is commonly 20uPa. would also be useful to know the fan speed.

revision.text:
{{Displaytitle|title=Stack trace}} {{Java Programming/Navigation|previous=Preventing NullPointerException|next=Nesting Exceptions}} {{Java Programming/ExceptionsTopic/Nav}} __NOTOC__ Stack Trace is a list of method calls from the point when the application was started to the point where the exception was thrown. The most recent method calls are at the top. {| style="width: 100%;" |valign="top"|{{XCode|1='''Code listing 6.3: StackTraceExample.java''' public class StackTraceExample { public static void main(String[] args) { method1(); } public static void method1() { method11(); } public static void method11() { method111(); } public static void method111() { throw new NullPointerException("Fictitious NullPointerException"); } } }} |valign="top"|{{XConsole|1='''Output for Code listing 6.3''' 
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NullPointerException: Fictitious NullPointerException
at StackTraceExample.method111(StackTraceExample.java:15)
at StackTraceExample.method11(StackTraceExample.java:11)
at StackTraceExample.method1(StackTraceExample.java:7)
at StackTraceExample.main(StackTraceExample.java:3)
}} |} The stack trace can be printed to the standard error by calling the public void printStackTrace() method of an exception. From Java 1.4, the stack trace is encapsulated into an array of a java class called java.lang.StackTraceElement. The stack trace element array returned by Throwable.getStackTrace() method. Each element represents a single stack frame. All stack frames except for the one at the top of the stack represent a method invocation. The frame at the top of the stack represents the execution point at which the stack trace was generated. Typically, this is the point at which the throwable corresponding to the stack trace was created. A stack frame represents the following information: {{XExample|1='''Code section 6.24: Stack frame.''' public StackTraceElement(String declaringClass, String methodName, String fileName, int lineNumber); }} Creates a stack trace element representing the specified execution point. == Converting the stack trace into string == Many times for debugging purposes, we'd like to convert the stack trace to a {{java:String}} so we can log it to our log file. The following code shows how to do that: {{XExample|1='''Code section 6.25: Save the stack trace.''' import java.io.StringWriter; import java.io.PrintWriter; ... Exception e = new NullPointerException(); StringWriter outError = new StringWriter(); e.printStackTrace(new PrintWriter(outError)); String errorString = outError.toString(); // Do whatever you want with the errorString }} {{Todo|Add some exercises like the ones in [[Java Programming/Variables#Kinds of variables|Variables]]}} {{Java Programming/Navigation|previous=Preventing NullPointerException|next=Nesting Exceptions}} {{Status|75%}} {{BookCat}}

Find out [[WB:WIW|what this means]]. * To sign your name (on talk pages), use four tildes, like this: ~~~~ * For help in using the wiki, see [[Using Wikibooks]]. * For information about the community here, see [[Wikibooks Community]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold|be bold]], and have fun! |} Come introduce yourself at the [[WB:SLN|new users]] page. If you have any questions, you can ask there or contact me personally.'''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 22:08, 22 November 2007 (UTC) == Copyright problem with [[:Image:Adapted ARCS.jpg]] == {{mbox|type=warning|msg= Thanks for uploading [[:Image:Adapted ARCS.jpg]]. The [[w:Wikimedia Foundation|Wikimedia Foundation]] is very careful about what Wikibooks includes because of [[w:United States copyright law|copyright law]], and requires that we maintain a strict [[Wikibooks:Copyright|copyright policy]]. [[:Image:Adapted ARCS.jpg]] and other files you uploaded may soon be deleted unless we can determine the copyright holder and status. The copyright holder is usually the creator, the creator's employer, or the last person who was transferred ownership rights. Please take the time to read [[Wikibooks:Media]] to learn more about what copyright information is required to satisfy our requirements and remember to include this important information for every file that you upload in the future as well. Please edit image descriptions pages directly to add this information; there's no need to upload the image again. If you have any questions, feel free to contact me, or ask another Wikibookian at the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|help desk]]. See {{UserImages}} for a complete list of your uploads which may get deleted soon.
Thank you. '''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|Mike.lifeguard]]''' | [[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|talk]] 22:08, 22 November 2007 (UTC)}}
'''[[User:LipeFontoura|Lipe]]'''<sup>[[User talk:LipeFontoura|(talk)]]</sup> [[Image:Flag of Brazil.svg|20px|border|Brazil]]

{{WikiProject Languages}}
This lesson is very long, so I minded splitting it in two. What do you think? --'''[[User:LipeFontoura|Lipe]]'''<sup>[[User talk:LipeFontoura|(talk)]]</sup> [[Image:Flag of Brazil.svg|20px|border|Brazil]] 22:15, 22 November 2007 (UTC)
== Grammatical Genders ==
Isn't it misleading to use English as an example of a language with grammatical genders, define a language with grammatical genders as "every single word [having] a specific gender," and then point out that only "he," "she," and "it" have genders in English?
On page 15 of Steven Pinker's <u>The Language Instinct</u>, he says:
"The Kivunjo construction fits entirely inside the verb, which has seven prefixes and suffixes, two moods, and fourteen tenses; the verb agrees with its subject, its object, and its benefactive nouns, each of which comes in sixteen genders. (In case you are wondering, these "genders" do not pertain to thing like cross-dressers, transsexuals, hermaphrodites, androgynous people, and so on, as one reader of this chapter surmised. To a linguist, the term ''gender'' retains its original meaning of "kind," as in the related words ''generic'', ''genus'', and ''genre''. The Bantu "genders" refer to kinds like humans, animals, extended objects, clusters of objects, and body parts. It just happens that in many European languages the genders correspond to the sexes, at least in pronouns. For this reason the linguistic term ''gender'' has been pressed into service by nonlinguists as a convenient label for sexual dimorphism; the more accurate term ''sex'' seems to now be reserved as the polite way to refer to copulation.)"
Is it okay to have that quote?
I think it is appropriate to introduce basic linguistics that clarify differences from the native language, English, to the new language, Portuguese, and should be done consistently.

{{Talkarchive}} == [[Wikipedia:CPR summary]] authors and history == * 2005-10-02 12:08:06 [[Wikipedia:User:Terra Green|User:Terra Green]] (→3. Open the '''AIRWAY''' - best remove stuff from mouth *first*, else tilting head can make it drop further down) * 2005-06-06 16:38:11 [[Wikipedia:User:Dabbler|User:Dabbler]] '''m''' (→5. Give '''TWO EFFECTIVE RESCUE BREATHS''' - whether typo fix) * 2005-04-06 12:36:06 [[Wikipedia:User:130.246.135.176|User:130.246.135.176]] ((formatting again)) * 2005-04-06 12:34:51 [[Wikipedia:User:130.246.135.176|User:130.246.135.176]] (indent continued) * 2005-04-06 12:33:31 [[Wikipedia:User:130.246.135.176|User:130.246.135.176]] (indent to aid clarity of flow chart) * 2004-12-04 13:00:06 [[Wikipedia:User:Tjwood|User:Tjwood]] (→1. Check for '''DANGER''') * 2004-12-03 20:01:22 [[Wikipedia:User:Tjwood|User:Tjwood]] (→6. Look for signs of '''CIRCULATION''' - breathing is very unlikely to re-start, there is no need to check for this (see talk)) * 2004-12-03 19:56:42 [[Wikipedia:User:Tjwood|User:Tjwood]] (→3. Open the '''AIRWAY''') * 2004-12-03 19:55:55 [[Wikipedia:User:Tjwood|User:Tjwood]] (→1. Check for '''DANGER''' - remove "Signal the accident scene, designate someone to do the circulation." See talk,) * 2004-11-29 14:29:42 [[Wikipedia:User:Rama|User:Rama]] (→6. Look for signs of '''CIRCULATION''') * 2004-11-29 12:36:17 [[Wikipedia:User:Rama|User:Rama]] (→7. Commence '''CPR''') * 2004-11-29 12:34:56 [[Wikipedia:User:Rama|User:Rama]] (→6. Look for signs of '''CIRCULATION''') * 2004-11-29 12:33:35 [[Wikipedia:User:Rama|User:Rama]] * 2004-11-29 12:07:13 [[Wikipedia:User:Rama|User:Rama]] (→3. Open the '''AIRWAY''') * 2004-11-29 12:04:38 [[Wikipedia:User:Rama|User:Rama]] (→1. Check for '''DANGER''') * 2004-10-07 14:22:39 [[Wikipedia:User:Cdang|User:Cdang]] '''m''' (category:first aid) * 2004-09-23 21:42:51 [[Wikipedia:User:Tjwood|User:Tjwood]] '''m''' (layout) * 2004-09-23 21:33:41 [[Wikipedia:User:Tjwood|User:Tjwood]] (→4. Check for '''BREATHING''') * 2004-09-23 21:33:01 [[Wikipedia:User:Tjwood|User:Tjwood]] '''m''' (added numbers to the steps) * 2004-09-23 21:31:26 [[Wikipedia:User:Tjwood|User:Tjwood]] (Created summary article as discussed at Talk:Cardiopulmonary_resuscitation) = From [[Wikipedia:Talk:CPR summary]] = OK, I've had a shot at creating this article after the discussions at [[Talk:Cardiopulmonary resuscitation]]. It's based on the UK method of teaching CPR (as that is what I know), which is as far as I know universal in Britain and is very similar to methods used elsewhere. The method I've described is consistent with the current British ''First Aid Manual'' which is the definitive guide to First Aid teaching in the UK. I hope you don't feel the need to add all sorts of varitions in teaching technique to this article, please can those can be kept to the main [[Cardiopulmonary resuscitation]] article? I tried to lay the summary out as best I could using the limited formatting Wikipedia allows. I hope it makes things clear. I know this summary is not perfect, but it's a start. For one thing I think we need some decent photos or illustrations! [[User:Tjwood|Tjwood]] 21:51, 23 Sep 2004 (UTC) I have no idea what "Signal the accident scene, designate someone to do the circulation." means, so I removed it from the Danger section. If you can re-phrase it so that it makes sense then by all means add it back! It is not necessary to re-check breathing every minute; it is unlikely to re-start of its own accord and you will notice if the casualty starts breathing. There is no need to waste time checking. [[User:Tjwood|Tjwood]] 20:02, 3 Dec 2004 (UTC) :Sorry, I must have been very tired. I meant "Alert oncoming motorists". OK, sounds silly, but it's a major danger (the physician who set up all the rescue system in my town, and who kept telling everyone that the llife expectancy of a man on an autoroute was a few seconds, was stupidly ran over by a truck after an accident :/ ). For the breath, I was trained to check from time to time, especially in the beginning, but I'm agreed with you. [[User:Rama|Rama]] 20:39, 3 Dec 2004 (UTC) ::Ah, OK! I'll add a bit back about traffic especially. [[User:Tjwood|Tjwood]] 12:52, 4 Dec 2004 (UTC) == Formating == Perhaps we would like to change the formatting a little bit, as, since we aim at having very few text, the titles take lots of place, in proportion. I'll try to suggest something when I have the time to do so [[User:Rama|Rama]] 13:36, 4 Dec 2004 (UTC) What would you think of something like this : ----
CPR Summary : Dr '''ABCD'''
'''D'''anger, '''R'''esponse, '''A'''irways, '''B'''reath, '''C'''PR, '''D'''efibrillation
Assessing the situation
Check for '''D'''anger
to yourself and to the casualty. Remove any hazards. Make sure that you do not put yourself in danger. If you are near a road, ensure that you are clearly visible to traffic.
Check for '''R'''esponse
does the casualty respond to voice or painful stimulus? * If YES, check the casualty for other conditions and call for help if necessary. * If NO, shout for help now, and continue:
Cardio-Respiratory Reanimation
Check for '''A'''irways
tilt the head back and lift the chin. If necessary, remove any loose and obvious obstructions from the mouth.
Check for '''B'''reath
is the casualty breathing? * If YES, place the casualty in the Recovery position and call for help. * If NO: ** If you are not alone, ask a helper to call an ambulance and go to step 5. ** If you are alone ***If the patient is unconscious due to injury, drowning, or choking, or is the casualty a child or infant, carry out resuscitation for one minute then call for an ambulance. ***If the patient is not a child and is inconscious due to a malaise, call for an ambulance immediately, proceed : Give two effective rescue breaths. After the two breaths, check wether the respiration has restarted. If if the respiration has restarted, place the casualty in the Recovery position and call for help. Monitor the patient and ensure he does not stop breathing again.
Manage the '''C'''irculation
Monitor the circulation of the patient. *If there are signs of circulation, continue rescue breaths: 10 breaths a minute for an adult or 20 breaths a minute for a child. Repeat step 6 after every set of breaths, checking signs of circulation after every minute. *If they are absent : ** For an adult, alternate 15 chest compressions with 2 breaths **For a child or infant, give five compressions to one breath. :Continue CPR until emergency help takes over; the casualty moves or takes a breath; or you are too exhausted to continue. If a defibrillator arrives on the scene, it will have priority on the CPR; follow the indications given by the handler of the defibrillator.
'''D'''efibrillation
If a semi-automatic defibrillator arrives before the mobile medical unit, use it : #Remove all remaining clothes from the chest of the patient #Place the defibrillation patches #The defibrillator will give further instructions. If the analysis of the patient requires an interruption of the CPR, the defibrillator has the priority. #Do not touch the patient when giving shocks
---- I think one of the advantages in that we have to rely less on the IF... THEN... ELSE... GOTO... system which tends to confuse people (in my experience, people end up putting everybody in recovery position and cross fingers because it is the only thing that they remember :p). Perhaps you might not quite like the colours I have choosen; the reason why is that I am completey colour-blind, so I'll be obliged if you care to change them to more manageable colours for people who can actually see chrominance ! :p Thanks ! [[User:Rama|Rama]] 16:53, 4 Dec 2004 (UTC) PS: I've added the small part about the defibrillator because #and since the whole point of the CPR is to maximise the chances of success for the defibrillator #there are more and more of these things in public places, and some police units carry them around too, it would be a shame not to use a device which would be available just because you didn't think of it. #People should know that CPR might have to stop and be able to witness this without panicking. [[User:Rama|Rama]] 16:58, 4 Dec 2004 (UTC) :It's a good idea, but I'm not sure how well that formatting fits in with Wikipedia's style. All that HTML gets in the way of editing etc, and Wikipedia prefers to leave specific colour choices to the user's stylesheet rather than code it into the article. I have asked a question on the Village Pump about this: [[Wikipedia:Village_pump_%28policy%29#Page_formatting]]. The defibrillation part would be a good addition, although it might be worth pointing out that in many jurisdictions people should have training before attempting to use even a public access AED. [[User:Tjwood|Tjwood]] 17:59, 4 Dec 2004 (UTC) :: Yes, it certainly is not standard, but is some way, so is the page itself. Correct me if I did not understand the underlying idea, but we want something a little bit like a quick reference card, don't we ? Actually, we might even create a PDF file and a png with [[LaTeX]]... Well, I don't know, after all, you're the boss on this page, so you're the one who decides the orientation we want. I wouldn't like to make you uncomfortable just because I didn't get the point in the first place ! Cheers ! [[User:Rama|Rama]] 12:05, 5 Dec 2004 (UTC) :::Hey, I'm not the boss. This is Wikipedia, anyone can change whatever they want. I created this article as a result of some discussion on the main CPR article ([[Talk:Cardiopulmonary_resuscitation#This_page_is_too_complicated]]) which suggested that we did need a simple summary article so that someone wanting to refresh their knowledge of CPR did not get bogged down in the details in the main article. Ideally I think we would have some sort of quick reference card, but there are problems doing that on Wikipedia which is driven by content not design, and where articles must be easy for anyone to edit. PDF files are unfortunately not easy to edit.[[User:Tjwood|Tjwood]] 14:21, 5 Dec 2004 (UTC)

revision.text: {{documentation subpage}} {{high-risk|16,000+}} ===Usage=== This is an auxiliary template allowing to encode "|" within template parameters. It is necessary if the character is used in wiki table syntax. In other cases it is better to use "|". This template cannot be used for putting the character as text in a wiki table; in that case, again, "|" can be used. Note that no special template is needed for "!" (exclamation mark). This is a '''high risk template''', and it cannot be substituted. ===See also=== *[[Template:!!]] *[[Template:!-]] *[[Template:-!]] [[Category:Template namespace templates|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[ko:틀:!]]

{{recipesummary|Bread recipes|2 loaves|3 to 4 hours|3}} | [[Cookbook:Cuisine of France|French cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Vegetarian cuisine|vegetarian cuisine]] | [[Cookbook:Bread Recipes|bread recipes]]
=French Bread=
===Ingredients===
* 2 packages [[Cookbook:Yeast|active dry yeast]] * ½ [[Cookbook:Cup|cup]] warm [[Cookbook:Water|water]] (about 110°F) * 1 [[Cookbook:Tablespoon|tablespoon]] [[Cookbook:Salt|salt]] * 2 cups lukewarm water * 7 to 7½ cups [[Cookbook:Flour|flour]] * 1 [[Cookbook:Egg White|egg white]] * [[Cookbook:Cornmeal|corn meal]]
===Procedure===
# In a small bowl, soften yeast in warm water. # Combine salt and lukewarm water in large bowl. # [[Cookbook:Beat|Beat]] in 2 cups flour. # Blend in yeast, and stir in enough flour to make stiff dough. # Turn out dough on floured surface. # Knead 10 to 15 minutes, working in last of flour (you may want to do this with a heavy duty [[Cookbook:Mixer|electric mixer]] with [[Cookbook:Dough Hook|dough hooks]]). # Form into a ball and put in greased bowl, turning to grease top, then cover with a cloth. # Rise until doubled (until a finger impression stays), about an hour, depending on temperature. # Punch down dough, turn out on floured surface, and divide in half. # Cover dough and rest for 10 minutes. # Shape each half of dough into a 5 by 12-[[Cookbook:Inch|inch]] rectangle. # Roll up each portion tightly, starting on the long side, sealing as you roll, taper if you like. # Place each loaf diagonally, seam side down, on a greased [[Cookbook:Cookie Sheet|baking sheet]] sprinkled with [[Cookbook:Cornmeal|corn meal]]. # Slash loaf tops ¼ inch diagonally, every 2½ inches with floured sharp knife or razor blade. # Beat egg white until foamy, add a tablespoon water. # Brush top and sides of loaves with egg mixture. # Cover with damp cloth, not touching loaves (drape cloth over inverted glasses). # Turn on [[Cookbook:Oven|oven]] to preheat to [[Cookbook:Oven_temperatures|375°F]]. # Let loaves rise until doubled, 60 to 75 minutes. # [[Cookbook:Bake|Bake]] until light brown, about 20 minutes. # Brush loaves with egg mixture again. # Bake another 15 to 20 minutes, or until done. # Cool on [[Cookbook:Wire Rack|wire racks]].
===Tips, Notes, and Variations===
* To get a rapid initial rise, use water about 130-135°F, and pour into bowl with '''yeast mixed with initial flour and salt''' and start mixing. * All rising should be in a warm place, like near the refrigerator. * A baking stone, ceramic brick, or even an iron skillet or griddle preheated in the oven (to place the the baking sheet on) will give a good "spring" or quick rise when the loaves are first placed in the oven. * For even crispier crust, brush each time with plain water.
[[Category:Inexpensive recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:French recipes|Bread, French]] [[Category:Baked recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Bread recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Egg recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]] [[Category:Vegetarian recipes|{{PAGENAME}}]]

{{recipe}} ==Ingredient== *3 cups (~750 mL) polar liquid ([[Cookbook:Water|water]], [[Cookbook:Milk|milk]], or some combination of these) *1 cup (~250 mL) coarse ground [[Cookbook:Cornmeal|cornmeal]] or [[w:Polenta|polenta]] *Butter and/or olive oil to taste (likely in the range of 1-2 tablespoons (15-30 mL)) *Salt *[[Cookbook:Parmesan Cheese|Parmesan cheese]], to taste
==Equipment== *Stove *Heavy pot with lid *Wooden spoon or similar
==Procedure==
Bring the liquid to a boil in a heavy pot. If you're using milk, keep an eye on it: it can easily boil over and make a mess all over the place in seconds. When the liquid is at a boil, add a pinch or so of salt. Add the polenta, stirring frequently to avoid lumps and form a stable suspension. Cover pot and turn to low, checking on it occasionally. Add more liquid if necessary. The polenta will be finished in approximately 45 minutes. Polenta can be kept on low heat for up to 20 minutes or allowed to cool for future use.

{{recipe}}
==Ingredients== *Double batch [[Cookbook:Basic Polenta|basic polenta]] *6 Boneless pork chops, 4 cm thick, approx 1 kg total *1 28 oz can of tomatoes, preferably "fire roasted" or similar *1 large carrot, peeled *1 medium onion, peeled *15 mL Olive Oil *15 mL butter *4 cloves garlic, peeled
==Equipment== *Stove *Knife, cutting board *Large sauté pan *Blender (a potato masher will work, and a stick blender would be perfect) *Meat thermometer
==Procedure== # Slice onion into 1 cm half-rings. Start Polenta. #Once the polenta is stable, sweat onions with olive oil and butter. #When onions are translucent, clear spaces for the six pork chops, and put the pork chops into these spaces. #Lightly brown the pork chops on both sides, remove from pan and set aside. Allow fond to develop slightly, then deglaze with 1/4 of the tomatoes. #Grind the rest of the tomatoes, along with the garlic, in a blender until garlic a rough paste is formed. Then, add to the onion mixture. #Turn heat to high, and allow sauce to simmer and darken slightly in color. When this occurs, turn heat to low. #Finely chop the carrot and stir it in, then nestle the pork chops into the sauce and allow to simmer until the pork chops are done to your liking, about 20 minutes or so. #Serve as soon as possible. To serve, spoon polenta on to plates or bowls and place pork chop and sauce on top.

== Motivation == You have a [[w:Directed Acyclic Graph|Directed Acyclic Graph]] (DAG) to track things such as a dependancy graph. You want to sort in input DAG of nodes so that in the output reflects the dependancy structure. The [[w:Topological sorting| Topological Sort]] of a Directed Acyclic Graph puts nodes in a sequence such that every node references only preceding nodes. This ordering is needed for example in scheduling processes in a Pipeline. For example, given a DAG defined as
the topological order would be:
The definition of topological order can be simply expressed in XQuery: 
declare function local:topological-sorted($nodes) as xs:boolean {
    every $n in $nodes satisfies
          every $id in $n/ref/@id 
                 satisfies $id = $n/preceding::node/@id
};
A recursive algorithm is also straightforward: 
declare function local:topological-sort($unordered, $ordered )   {
    if (empty($unordered))
    then $ordered
    else
        let $nodes := $unordered [ every $id in ref/@id satisfies $id = $ordered/@id]
        return 
          if ($nodes)
          then local:topological-sort( $unordered except $nodes, ($ordered, $nodes ))
          else ()  (: cycles so no order possible :)
};
which is invoked as 
let $graph :=
 
    
       
       
    
    
       
    
    
 
let $sortedNodes := {local:topological-sort($graph/node,())}
return local:topological-sorted($sortedNodes)
===Explanation=== $ordered is initially the original sequence, $ordered is empty. At each iteration, the set of nodes which are dependant only on the ordered nodes are calculated and these are removed from the unordered nodes and added to the ordered nodes. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:XQuery]]

revision.comment: /* How can you keep your ears healthy? */ expanded
revision.text:
==What does an ear look like?==
Looked from the outside, our ears have a roughly oval shape. Several crest like structures, elevations and creases make the surface of the ear look crumpled. In the middle, the auditory canal leads to inner structures of the ear which are the middle and inner ear. The middle ear starts with the eardrum which is connected with the inner ear by some tiny bones (the ossicles). The inner ear called cochlea is a spiral.
==What is the function of the ear?==
The outer ear collects air waves, modifies them by its surface and leads them through the auditory canal to the eardrum. Like with a trampoline, air waves bounce off the eardrum which transmits these movements to the inner ear. The inner ear can separate different pitches of sounds in air waives and gets excited at distinct part each corresponding to a distinct pitch. The inner ear then transmits this information to the brain which makes us experience sounds. The inner ear also has the capabilities to measure body movements which helps us orient with eyes closed or in the dark, and controls our balance.
==How does the ear interact with other parts of the body?==
The inner ear is connected with the brain via the auditory nerve which carries sound and body movement information.
==How can you keep your ears healthy?==
The ear is a very sensitive organ that can easily be damaged if it is exposed to too high sound levels. There are a few things you can do to keep your ears safe: * Do not turn your music up too loud * Protect your ears from insects and bugs.
{{BookCat}}

revision.comment: [[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], typos fixed: dutch → Dutch using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
== Nouns == :The word ''drink'' is the same in both English and Dutch, when you use the verb: I drink - ik drink. :However, for ''a drink'' in Dutch you say ''een dr'''a'''nkje''. :It is the diminutive of ''drank'' which means ''beverage''.
Let's look at some ''dranken'':
de koffie - coffee
de thee - tea
de wijn - wine
de cider - cider
het water - water
het bier - beer
het citroensap - lemonade
het appelsap - apple juice
de witte wijn - white wine
de rode wijn - red wine
de droge wijn - dry wine
de zoete wijn - sweet wine
== Verbs ==
'''"Drinken" is a very common verb in Dutch. But, be careful! "Drinken" is a strong verb with vowel changes in the past tense and the past participle.'''
<u>Present</u>
ik drink we drinken
je drinkt jullie drinken
hij drinkt ze drinken
<u>Past</u>
ik dronk we dronken
je dronk jullie dronken
hij dronk ze dronken
<u>Past Participle</u>: gedronken
== In Conversation == '''How do you order drinks in Dutch? Take a look:'''
Waiter: Wilt u iets drinken?
Customer: Ja, graag!
Waiter: Wat wilt u drinken?
Customer: Om te beginnen wil ik een glaasje rode wijn. Wat beveel je aan?
Waiter: De huiswijn is Merlot.
Costumer: Een glaasje merlot. Dat zou prima zijn!
Waiter: Dat is alles?
Costumer: Ja.
''moments later''
Waiter: Alstublieft, één glaasje witte wijn.
Customer: Maar dat is niet wat ik besteld heb. Ik had graag ''rode'' wijn.
Waiter: Oh, sorry!
