revision.comment: Hm, possibly true, but it is widely believed that Old Norse and Icelandic are quite different phonologically.
revision.text:
{{Icelandic contents}} '''Inngangur'''
:''Introduction'' Welcome to the world of Wikibooks' language guide in learning the Icelandic language. You are here either because you have an interest in learning this wonderful ancient and modern language, you are either Icelandic or have Icelandic blood, you have a passion for Scandinavian or Nordic languages, you are connected somehow to Iceland, you want to fully grasp the Icelandic sagas in its original language, you will take a trip to Iceland soon and want to communicate with the locals, or you just want to learn a language for fun. Whatever the reason may be for wanting to learn the language, you are here now and we are here to help you learn the language. '''Velkomin!''' (Welcome) [[Image:Map of Iceland.svg|300px|thumb|right|Map of the Republic of Iceland, located between Greenland and Scotland.]] Icelandic is the mother tongue of about 320,000 people in the world. It is the only official language of the Republic of Iceland. The language has existed for a very long time, though called different names (such as Old Norse). Icelandic is one of the most unchanged and purest languages in the world. It is said that a speaker of Icelandic would be able to talk with a Viking hundreds of years ago without much difficulty. A speaker of Icelandic can also read the sagas without much difficulty either. The Icelandic language belongs to the Western Scandinavian language group along with [[Faroese]], the language of the Faroe Islands. It is possible to see many connections between the other Scandinavian languages too, such as [[Norwegian]], [[Danish]], and [[Swedish]]. If you are familiar with any other Scandinavian language, learning Icelandic shouldn't be a problem for you. The most difficult aspect to grasp in Icelandic would be the complex grammar. There is a case system, like in [[German]] and [[Latin]], that might frustrate English speakers or those who are not familiar with grammatical cases. This means that words will change form or have endings depending on what function of the sentence is has. Even names will change. If you have studied Latin before, you might be able to see some similiarities between the grammar aspects of the language. Do not be discouraged by the grammar though, this book is not a book designed to just drill grammar rules into your head. We will start off with the basics so you can communicate effectively in Icelandic, then slowly introduce grammar rules so you will be able to construct sentences of your own. Remember that all languages are difficult to learn. Do not expect Icelandic to come easy, because nothing in life worth having comes easy. If you start to become frustrated, just think about how well you can speak English or whatever your mother tongue might be. If you can expand your vocabulary in English, then you should have no problem doing it in a foreign language. The feeling of being able to communicate in a foreign language is rewarding, especially that of Icelandic. ''[[:w:Icelandic language|Read more]] about the Icelandic language'' == How to use this book == This book is a free content open source guide in learning the Icelandic language. Though it can be edited by anyone, it is also being monitored by the authors and administrators of this book and Wikibooks, to assure you 100% accuracy. So do not be discouraged about using this book as a primary or secondary reference in your language studies as this book is not giving you any false information. The book is set up in step-by-step lessons which will introduce the language like a classroom setting and similar to a textbook style tutorial. It will commence with the basics of the language, and gradually introduce grammar aspects of the language, rather than give you a bunch of grammar explanations and a massive list of vocabulary to learn on your own. The book is set up accordingly so you can go at your own pace whether you are a fast learner or prefer to take your time. Do not skip over the '''Málfræði''' (Grammar) sections. Though sometimes it might seem like a lot, it is essential information to read and understand. Icelandic grammar is difficult, but we will try to explain it as easy as possible for a simple understanding. Use the navigation header above to navigate to the next lesson, a previous lesson, or the pronunciation guide. There will also be appendices (grammar references) at the end of the book which you can navigate to. At the end of each lesson there will be small exercises to test yourself on the knowledge you've gained and accumulated in the previous lessons. Do not be tempted to skip over them! It is very easy to just say ''Oh! I have done enough, I know the answers, no problem at all''. Try to work on each question and check yourself. This will only improve your knowledge on the language. Learning a language is a tough challenge, but with this book, we will try to make it as informative, fun, and motivative as possible to help you learn the Icelandic language. A good way to practise is reading the [[:w:is:Forsíða|Icelandic wikipedia]]! Listen to Icelandic radio too at [http://www.utvarpsaga.is Útvarpsaga.is] live. (Click on ''On air'' (''Hlusta í beinni'') in the left corner and it will open in Windows Media Player). ''Útvarp Saga'' is more or less geared to older people, but it is the radio station that contains the most talk. It might be a great way for a learner to understand conversation in Icelandic. '''Gangi þér vel!'''

{{WikiProject Languages}}
The first known appearance of this poem was inscribed inside the cover of my mother Winifred Lenore "Winnie" Robertson Parkerson's (b. 1915) Latin text at Longview High School; Longview, TX; early part of twentieth centry, as she reported same to me. Ever since that time it has been inscribed inside the cover of high-school Latin texts by some students, as was done by me during my two years of Latin I and Latin II at Nacogdoches High School; Nacogdoches, TX (late 1950's).
Also, inspired by this little poem, I wrote the following one:
"True Penance"
Latin is a language
As hard as it can be.
You can speak it to your neighbor,
You can speak it to a tree.
Neither will understand you,
No, not in the least;
That is, unless your neighbor
Is a Roman Catholic priest.
Then you can tell him, MEA CULPA, MEA CULPA, MEA CULPA!:
That Latin confessional sen'ence;
And he'll tell you go and sin no more
And read Latin as your penance.
-by Hardy Parkerson, Atty.; Lake Charles, Louisiana.
:The poem also appears in a number of other places; Google Books finds a citation in a 1905 classical journal but no doubt it's older than that. [[User:Marnanel|Marnanel]] 18:48, 2 December 2007 (UTC)

== Welcome message ==
Hello, and '''[[Wikibooks:Welcome, newcomers|welcome]]''' to [[Wikibooks]]!
Here are some tips to help you get started: * To learn the wiki-markup-language syntax, see [[Help:Editing]]. * You should sign your name on Talk and vote pages using four tildes, like this: ~~~~ **There is a box at the top of the edit window that will insert this, too; it looks like part of a signature. * Remember to conduct any editing experiments in the [[Wikibooks:Sandbox|sandbox]]. * You can tell the community something about yourself in your userpage. ** You can get to this page by clicking the tab at the top of the page labeled with your registered username. * Wikibooks is a collection of open-source textbooks. ([[WB:WIW|What is Wikibooks]]). * If you are a '''Wikipedian''', see [[Wikibooks:Wikibooks for Wikipedians]] for a primer on how things work here (it's a little different). ** If you want to base your work here on materials from Wikipedia, please use [[WB:RFI]] (requests for importation) to bring the material over in compliance with the GFDL. * If you're an '''instructor''' and plan on using Wikibooks for a class project, see [[Wikibooks:Guidelines for class projects]] * Please say hello at the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]] with any questions or ideas. * Eventually, you might want to read the [[Wikibooks:Manual of Style|Manual of Style]] and [[Wikibooks:Policies and guidelines|Policies and Guidelines]]. ** Help us by participating in policy and guideline creation. ** Please take a look at [[Wikibooks:Naming policy]] before starting a new book. * Remember to maintain a [[Wikibooks:Neutral point of view|Neutral point of view]]. * Explore, [[Wikibooks:Be bold in updating pages|be bold in editing pages]], and have fun!
You will find more resources in [[Wikibooks:Community Portal|Community Portal]]. If you want to ask a question, visit the [[Wikibooks:Study help desk|Study help desk]], the [[Wikibooks:Reading room|Reading Room]], [[Wikibooks:IRC channels|IRC channel]] or [[User_talk:Panic2k4|ask me personally on my talk page]]. For site news, see the [[WB:BB|Bulletin board]]. It might be a good idea to add that page to your "[[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]]" so that you can see when any new information is posted there. You can do that by clicking the tab labeled "watch" at the top of the page.
Good luck! --[[User:Panic2k4|Panic]] 19:09, 2 December 2007 (UTC)

page.title: Teaching Elementary School Health Education/Mental and Emotional Health/Developing Good Character and Improving Self-Esteem

revision.comment: [[WP:AWB/T|Typo fixing]], typos fixed: memebers → members using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
To possess good character, one's action must reflect responsible values. Here are some guidelines to teach your students to show self respect. *Pay attention to your appearance. *Make a list of responsible actions and review the list often. *Be a friend to yourself by enjoying activities, such as hobbies, by yourself. *Write your feelings in a journal. *Make spending time with family members a priority. *Care for other people in the way you would like to be cared for. *Let other people know what helps you feel special. *Support the interests of family members and friends, and ask them to support your interests. Click on the following link for a lesson plan where students help build self esteem of their peers. [http://eduref.org/cgi-bin/printlessons.cgi/Virtual/Lessons/Health/Mental_Health/MEH0001.html Chain of Compliments]
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Teaching Elementary School Health Education/Mental and Emotional Health/Social-Emotional Environment

revision.text:
The social-emotional environment is the quality of the contacts a person has with the people with whom they interact. This is important in your students' lives. Their interactions with peers and adults influence their social and emotional well being. Therefore by creating a positive social-emotional environment in your classroom improves upon their health status at school.
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Teaching Elementary School Health Education/Mental and Emotional Health/Social-Emotional Environment and Health Status

revision.text:
A positive social-emotional environment exists when a person recieves plenty of social-emotional boosters. Creating a positive social-emotional environment is important. Click on the following link for a lesson over creating a positive social-emotional classroom. [http://www.teachervision.fen.com/classroom-management/lesson-plan/2240.html?detoured=1 Peacable Classroom] Here are the ten ways that a postive social-emotional environment improves health status: * Improves self respect * Provides support for responsible behavior * Provides the support and encouragment you need to take calculated risks * Allows you to correct mistakes, forgive yourself and move on * Helps you to be resilient * Reduces Stress * Helps to prevent and relieve depression
{{BookCat}}

You don't have to [[Special:Userlogin|log in]] to read or edit articles on Wikibooks, but creating an account is quick, free and non-intrusive, requires no personal information, and gives you many benefits, including: *The use of a username of your choice *The ability to view all your contributions via a "My contributions" link *Your own [[wikipedia:user page|user page]] *Your own talk page which, if you choose, also allows users to send you messages without knowing your e-mail address *The use of your own personal [[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]] to which you can add articles that interest you *The ability to rename pages. *The ability to [[Special:Upload|upload images]] *The ability to customize the appearance and behavior of the website *The eligibility to become an [[Help:Administrators|administrator]] *The right to be heard in votes and elections *Your IP address will no longer be visible to other users.

page.title: Teaching Elementary School Health Education/Mental and Emotional Health/Personality Characteristics that Promote Good Health
Teaching Elementary School Health Education/Mental and Emotional Health/Anger Management Skills

revision.text:
Anger is an emotional that we do not want in our classrooms. It is an emotion that varies in intensity from mild irritation to intense rage that is often accompanied by physiological changes that prepare the body for fighting. Our students may have anger built up inside causing hidden anger, which is accompanied by negative, cruel remarks to others, being sarcastic, procrastinating, blowing up easily, being bored, and sighing frequently. We must teach our students anger management skills. They are healthful ways to control and express anger. Click on this link for a lesson dealing with anger management skills and how to address them. [http://www.nytimes.com/learning/teachers/lessons/20020528tuesday.html Anger Management] Teaching the following skills will help your students to manage anger * Keep an anger self-inventory * Use self statements to control anger * Use I-messages instead of You-messages * Write a letter * Write in a journal * Reduce the effects of anger cues with physical activity * Use safe physical actions to blow off steam * Keep a sense of humor * Rehearse what to do in situations that you know your anger triggers * Talk with a parent or mentor
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Teaching Elementary School Health Education/Mental and Emotional Health/Mental Alertness and Mental Health

revision.text:
We must teach our students to be alert, watchful and use their intelligence. When people are mentally alert they understand that their minds need excercise just as their bodies do. By promoting their mental health, students will feel good about themsevles, build happy relationships and set realistic goals for themselves. As teachers we want our students lives to be happy and positive. Although life does throw some curve balls. We must educate our students to respond to these problems in a healthly way. Click here for a lesson over emotions. By teaching our students about emotions and how to deal with them, mental alertness will grow and mental health will stay high. [http://eduref.org/cgi-bin/printlessons.cgi/Virtual/Lessons/Health/Mental_Health/MEH0002.html Emotional Puppets]
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Teaching Elementary School Health Education/Mental and Emotional Health/Understanding How Stress Affects Health Status

revision.text:
Stress is the body's response to the demands of daily living. A stressor is a source or cause of stress. For our students stress can be phyiscal, mental, social, or environmental. There are two types of stress that can effect our students. They include: * Eustress- A healthful response to a stressor that produces positive results. * Distresss- A harmful response to a stressor that produces negative results. Since stress has a holistic effect, it can effect other areas of health than just mental and emotional health. These other areas include, family and social health, growth and development, nutrition, personal health and physical activity, alcohol, tobacco and other drugs, communicable and chronic diseases, consumer and community health, environmental health, injury prevention and safety. Here are several lesson plans over stress and how to deal with it with our students. * [http://www.education-world.com/a_tsl/archives/02-1/lesson045.shtml Striking Out Stress] * [http://school.discoveryeducation.com/lessonplans/programs/takingCareOfMe/ Taking Care of Me]
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Teaching Elementary School Health Education/Mental and Emotional Health/Stress-Management Skills

revision.text:
When stress arises for our students, we must introduce stress-management skills. These are techniques that can be used to cope with the harmful effects produced by stress. One skill is to learn to do something about the cause of stress. The second skill is to keep the body healthy and relieving anxiety. By teaching the following stress management skills, our students will learn to not let stress affect them. * Use responsible decision making skills * Get plenty of rest and asleep * Participate in physical activities * Use time management plan * Write in a journal * Have close friends * Talk with parents or other trusted adults * Help others * Express affection in appropriate ways * Care for pets * Change our outlook * Keep a sense of humor * Use breathing techniques
{{BookCat}}
#REDIRECT [[Icelandic/Lesson 1]]

page.title: Teaching Elementary School Health Education/Mental and Emotional Health/Recognizing Childhood and Adolescent Depression

revision.text:
Unfortunately some of our students may experience depression. As teachers we will need to guide them to seek assistance or help when feeling depressed. Some of the characteristics of depression include: * Persistent sadness * Loss of pleasure and interest in activities once enjoyed * Fatigue or loss of energy * Restlessness, irritability * Sleep Disturbances * Weight or appetite changes * Lack of concentration or difficulty making decisions * Feelings of worthlessness, hopelessness, or guilt * Thoughts of suicide or death When this characteristics are apparent in a student, conference with the student to see how they feel. They may feel confident in talking to you. See Treatment for Depression for those who are exhibit these traits or are diagnosed with depression. For more information about depression click this link. [http://www.lessons4living.com/depression.htm Depression]
{{BookCat}}

page.title: Teaching Elementary School Health Education/Mental and Emotional Health/Treatment for Depression

revision.text:
Children and adolescents who are depressed often suffer for years before they are diagnosed. Few who need treatment for depression actually seek help. The following are types of treatment for depression. * Physical examination * Medication * Therapy These forms of treatment along with strategies that teachers and other adults can use is important for student's depression. Help your student cope with their depression by encouraging them to: * Talk to an adult, parent, guardian, or you * Stay connected with friends * Practice healthful behaviors * Use anger management skills * Practice stress management skills * Aviod the use of alcohol and other drugs
{{BookCat}}
{{babel|en|fr-3}} As I am not very active here, please see [[m:User:Greeves|my page on Meta-Wiki]] or the [[w:User:Greeves|English Wikipedia]]. Thanks!

page.title: Teaching Elementary School Health Education/Mental and Emotional Health/Loss and Grief

revision.text:
Our students may lose a family member or friend close to them. Loss is a feeling that occurs when someone dies or a life situation changes or ends in a loss. Grief is intense emotional suffering caused by a loss, disaster, or misfortune. Some causes of loss and grief for our students may include: * Change in the family (divorce, death of a family memeber, loss of job, serious or terminal illness) * Changes in living conditions (eviction, homeless shelter) * Death of a friend * Suicide * Death of a well-known person * Tragedies in the news * The end of something special (graduation, moving away) * Holidays (Feelings of loss and grief can intensify during holiday seasons) Click here for a lesson helping students deal with loss or grief. [http://eduref.org/cgi-bin/printlessons.cgi/Virtual/Lessons/Health/Mental_Health/MEH0200.html Responding to Social Crises]
{{BookCat}}

==Welcome!== [[Help:Welcome, newcomers|Welcome to Wikibooks]], a collection of open-content textbooks! You don't have to [[Special:Userlogin|log in]] to read or edit articles on Wikibooks, but creating an account is quick, free and non-intrusive, requires no personal information, and gives you many benefits, including: *The use of a username of your choice *The ability to view all your contributions via a "My contributions" link *Your own [[wikipedia:user page|user page]] *Your own talk page which, if you choose, also allows users to send you messages without knowing your e-mail address *The use of your own personal [[Special:Watchlist|watchlist]] to which you can add articles that interest you *The ability to rename pages. *The ability to [[Special:Upload|upload images]] *The ability to customize the appearance and behavior of the website *The eligibility to become an [[Help:Administrators|administrator]] *The right to be heard in votes and elections *Your IP address will no longer be visible to other users.
We hope that you choose to become a Wikibookian and '''[[Special:Userlogin|create an account]]'''. Feel free to ask me any questions you may have on my talk page. By the way, make sure to sign your posts and comments with four tildes ('''~~~~'''), which will let others know who left it.
'''– [[User:Mike.lifeguard|<font color="Indigo">Mike.lifeguard</font>]]''' | <sup>[[User talk:Mike.lifeguard|<font color="Indigo">talk</font>]]</sup> 01:23, 3 December 2007 (UTC)

{{Chess Opening Theory/Position|= |Pirc Defence| |rd|nd|bd|qd|kd|bd| |rd|= |pd|pd|pd| |pd|pd|pd|pd|= | | | |pd| |nd| | |= | | | | | | | | |= | | | |pl|pl| | | |= | | | | | | | | |= |pl|pl|pl| | |pl|pl|pl|= |rl|nl|bl|ql|kl|bl|nl|rl|= || }} =Pirc Defence= This is the main line of the Pirc Defence. Black immediately challenges the White center with his knight, which forces White to protect it. White has several options. Each one has its pluses and minuses. Black will, usually regardless of what White plays, play 3....g6 next and 4....Bg7. Fianchetto on the fourth move, however, is not always obligatory. In the systems with 4. Bd3 or 4.f3 Black often delays this thematic move, in order to discourage Bh6. Instead, he opts for queenside expansion with ...c6 and ...b5. ==Theory table== 1.e4 d6 2.d4 Nf6
3
Main Line [[/3. Nc3|Nc3]]

page.title: Chess Opening Theory/1. e4/1...d6/2. d4/2...Nf6/3. Nc3

revision.text:
{{Chess Opening Theory/Position|= |Pirc Defence| |rd|nd|bd|qd|kd|bd| |rd|= |pd|pd|pd| |pd|pd|pd|pd|= | | | |pd| |nd| | |= | | | | | | | | |= | | | |pl|pl| | | |= | | |nl| | | | | |= |pl|pl|pl| | |pl|pl|pl|= |rl| |bl|ql|kl|bl|nl|rl|= || }} =Pirc Defence= ===3.Nc3=== White replies to Black's developing move with a developing move of his own, 3.Nc3. The move is noncommittal, as the knight was probably going to go to c3 anyway. It protects the e-pawn and maintains White's large center. ==Theory table== :'''1. e4 d6 2. d4 Nf6 3. Nc3'''
4

page.title: Chess Opening Theory/1. e4/1...d6/2. d4/2...Nf6/3. Nc3/3...g6

revision.text:
{{Chess Opening Theory/Position|= |Pirc Defence| |rd|nd|bd|qd|kd|bd| |rd|= |pd|pd|pd| |pd|pd| |pd|= | | | |pd| |nd|pd| |= | | | | | | | | |= | | | |pl|pl| | | |= | | |nl| | | | | |= |pl|pl|pl| | |pl|pl|pl|= |rl| |bl|ql|kl|bl|nl|rl|= || }} =Pirc Defence= ===3...g6=== Black continues with his hypermodern plan of fianchettoing the bishop to pressure White's center. The bishop creates a masked attack on d4, and also helps to control the center. White still has yet to make a decision about his center, and he will do so with his next move. ==Theory table== 1.e4 d6 2.d4 Nf6 3.Nc3 g6

page.title: Chess Opening Theory/1. e4/1...d6/2. d4/2...Nf6/3. Nc3/3...g6/4. f4

revision.comment: moved [[Chess Opening Theory/1. e4/1...d6/2. d4/2...Nf6/3. Nc3/3...g6/3. f4]] to [[Chess Opening Theory/1. e4/1...d6/2. d4/2...Nf6/3. Nc3/3...g6/4. f4]]
revision.text:
{{Chess Opening Theory/Position|= |Austrian Attack| |rd|nd|bd|qd|kd|bd| |rd|= |pd|pd|pd| |pd|pd| |pd|= | | | |pd| |nd|pd| |= | | | | | | | | |= | | | |pl|pl|pl| | |= | | |nl| | | | | |= |pl|pl|pl| | | |pl|pl|= |rl| |bl|ql|kl|bl|nl|rl|= || }} =Austrian Attack= ===4.f4=== This is White's most aggressive variation against the Pirc Defense. White gets in an immediate threat, albeit a not-so-dangerous one, of e5. Black's plan here is usually to develop normally, as there really is no good way of preventing e5. As e5 is not so dangerous anyway, Black usually continues development. ==Theory table== :1.e4 d6 2.d4 Nf6 3.Nc3 g6 4.f4
4
Main Line ...
[[/4...Bg7/]]		 =
{{ChessMid}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{BCO2}} {{Chess Opening Theory/Footer}}

page.title: Chess Opening Theory/1. e4/1...d6/2. d4/2...Nf6/3. Nc3/3...g6/4. f4/4...Bg7

revision.text:
{{Chess Opening Theory/Position|= |Austrian Attack| |rd|nd|bd|qd|kd| | |rd|= |pd|pd|pd| |pd|pd|bd|pd|= | | | |pd| |nd|pd| |= | | | | | | | | |= | | | |pl|pl|pl| | |= | | |nl| | | | | |= |pl|pl|pl| | | |pl|pl|= |rl| |bl|ql|kl|bl|nl|rl|= || }} =Austrian Attack= ===4...Bg7=== This is Black's normal continuation. Black continues to aim his pieces at the growing White center. White's center poses a growing threat to Black's position. The advance of the e-pawn for White would snuff out the bishop's activity, so Black must find some way to prevent e5. He is safe for now for tactical reasons, but preparation by White will force Black to take preventive measures. ==Theory table== 1.e4 d6 2.d4 Nf6 3.Nc3 g6 4.f4 Bg7
4
Main Line [[/5. Nf3/]]
...		 =
{{ChessMid}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Chess Opening Theory/Footer}}

page.title: Chess Opening Theory/1. e4/1...d6/2. d4/2...Nf6/3. Nc3/3...g6/4. f4/4...Bg7/5. Nf3

revision.comment: moved [[Chess Opening Theory/1. e4/1...d6/2. d4/2...Nf6/3. Nc3/3...g6/3. f4/4...Bg7/5. Nf3]] to [[Chess Opening Theory/1. e4/1...d6/2. d4/2...Nf6/3. Nc3/3...g6/4. f4/4...Bg7/5. Nf3]]
revision.text:
{{Chess Opening Theory/Position|= |Austrian Attack| |rd|nd|bd|qd|kd| | |rd|= |pd|pd|pd| |pd|pd|bd|pd|= | | | |pd| |nd|pd| |= | | | | | | | | |= | | | |pl|pl|pl| | |= | | |nl| | |nl| | |= |pl|pl|pl| | | |pl|pl|= |rl| |bl|ql|kl|bl| |rl|= || }} =Austrian Attack= ===5. Nf3=== White supports e5 with his knight and threatens in earnest to advance his central pawns. Black has two choices. One is entirely defensive, but takes away from much of the force of the attack. The other, seen much more frequently than the former, is the choice of the world's top Pirc players. ==Theory table== :1.e4 d6 2.d4 Nf6 3.Nc3 g6 4.f4 Bg7 5.Nf3
4
...
[[/5...c5/]] 		=

{{Chess Opening Theory/Position|= |Austrian Attack:Dragon| |rd|nd|bd|qd|kd| | |rd|= |pd|pd| | |pd|pd|bd|pd|= | | | |pd| |nd|pd| |= | | |pd| | | | | |= | | | |pl|pl|pl| | |= | | |nl| | |nl| | |= |pl|pl|pl| | | |pl|pl|= |rl| |bl|ql|kl|bl| |rl|= || }} =Austrian Attack: Dragon= ===5...c5=== Black strikes at the center before White can make a move with it. His move may seem antipositional, as after 6.dxc5 dxc5 7.Qxd8+ Kxd8 8.Be3 b6 9.0-0-0+ Bd7 gives White an excellent game, due to Black's uncastled king and poor pawn position. However, Black can get a favorable [[Wikipedia:pawn structure|pawn structure]] by using a tactical trick. The reason for the variation's nickname is for the excellent pawn structure that Black can get out of it, the [[Opening theory in chess/1. e4/1...c5/2. Nf3/2...d6/3. d4/3...cxd4/4. Nxd4/4...Nf6/5. Nc3/5...g6|Sicilian Dragon]]. ==Theory table== :1.e4 d6 2.d4 Nf6 3.Nc3 g6 4.f4 Bg7 5.Nf3 c5
4

[[/6. Bb5+/]]		 =

[[/6. dxc5/]]		 =

[[/6. d5/]]		 =
{{ChessMid}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{BCO2}} {{Chess Opening Theory/Footer}}

{{Chess Opening Theory/Position|= |Austrian Attack:Dragon| |rd|nd|bd|qd|kd| | |rd|= |pd|pd| | |pd|pd|bd|pd|= | | | |pd| |nd|pd| |= | | |pl| | | | | |= | | | | |pl|pl| | |= | | |nl| | |nl| | |= |pl|pl|pl| | | |pl|pl|= |rl| |bl|ql|kl|bl| |rl|= || }} =Austrian Attack:Dragon= ===6.dxc5=== White chooses the simplest option, taking the pawn. Black's next move wins back a pawn and achieves a better pawn structure. The other option for White would be to ignore Black's threats and lose the pawn, in addition to getting an inferior position. ==Theory table== 1.e4 d6 2.d4 Nf6 3.Nc3 g6 4.f4 Bg7 5.Nf3 c5 6.dxc5
4

= Celx Scripting: Celestia object = == celestia == This object is predefined and gives access to all the celestia-related functionality available for Lua-scripts, either directly by methods of celestia, or indirectly by creating other objects which offer more functionality. == Methods == This chapter contains a list of all available celestia methods, which can be used on the predefined celestia object. === print === {{Celx:func|celestia:print}}({{Celx:arg|string:text}} [, {{Celx:arg|number:duration}}, {{Celx:arg|number:horig}}, {{Celx:arg|number:vorig}}, {{Celx:arg|number:hoffset}}, {{Celx:arg|number:voffset}}]) Print text on screen. Celestia supports UTF-8 encoded text strings for showing non-ASCII characters. {{Celx:argdesc| ; text: A string containing the message to be printed. : The string can contain newlines "\n" to break lines, or many special characters encoded in UTF-8. : It is also possible to use variables and text strings within the same print command. : This can be done by concatenating text strings and variables as follows: :* "String1 " .. variable1 .. "String2 " .. variable2 : For the more experienced CELX writer, it’s also possible to use Lua string functions on text, : for instance to merge and format text and variables (see Lua Reference Manual). ; duration [optional] : Number of seconds the text is shown. Default is 5. : Negative duration values are considered to be 1.5 seconds. ; horig [optional]: Horizontal origin of the text, -1 is left, 0 center, 1 right ; vorig [optional]: Vertical origin of the text, -1 is bottom, 0 center, 1 top ; hoffset [optional]: Horizontal offset relative to origin. ; voffset [optional]: Vertical Offset relative to origin. }} '''Notes:''' # By default, text is printed in white.
Celestia also has the possibility to set the text color prior to this method, using the {{Celx:v161}} [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#settextcolor|celestia:settextcolor()]] method. '''Example-1:'''
Position text on the screen: celestia:print("Middle", 3.0, 0, 0, -3, 0) wait(3.0) celestia:print("Bottom left", 3.0, -1, -1, 2, 4) wait(3.0) celestia:print("Top right", 3.0, 1, 1, -10, -4) wait(3.0) '''Example-2:'''
Print on more than 1 line and use text and variables: rearth = celestia:find("Sol/Earth"):radius() rmars = celestia:find("Sol/Mars"):radius() celestia:print("Earth radius is: " .. rearth .. " km.\nMars radius is: " .. rmars .. " km.", 5.0, -1, -1, 2, 4) wait(5.0) '''Example-3:'''
Print text and formatted variables: rearth = celestia:find("Sol/Earth"):radius() celestia:print(string.format("The radius of Earth is: %10.0f km.", rearth ), 5.0, -1, -1, 2, 4) wait(5.0)
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== flash === {{Celx:func|celestia:flash}}({{Celx:arg|string:text}} [, {{Celx:arg|number:duration}}]) Print text on screen, similar to print. {{Celx:argdesc| ; text: A string containing the message to be printed. The string can contain newlines "\n" to break lines, or many special characters encoded in UTF-8. ; duration [optional]: Number of seconds the text is shown. Default is 5. : Negative duration values are considered to be 1.5 seconds. }} '''Example:''' celestia:flash("This string is flashed on your screen for 10 seconds.", 10.0) wait(10.0)
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== show === {{Celx:func|celestia:show}}({{Celx:arg|string:renderflag}}) Enable one or many rendering features. This method exists for backward compatibility with older scripts. The [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setrenderflags|celestia:setrenderflags()]] method should be used instead. {{Celx:argdesc| ; renderflag: String describing the render-feature to be enabled. Must be one of: :* orbits :* cloudmaps :* constellations :* galaxies :* planets :* stars :* nightmaps :* eclipseshadows :* ringshadows :* comettails :* boundaries :* markers :* automag :* atmospheres :* grid :* smoothlines :* lightdelay :* partialtrajectories :* {{Celx:v150}} cloudshadows :* {{Celx:v150}} nebulae :* {{Celx:v150}} openclusters :* {{Celx:v160}} globulars :* {{Celx:v160}} ecliptic :* {{Celx:v160}} equatorialgrid :* {{Celx:v160}} galacticgrid :* {{Celx:v160}} eclipticgrid :* {{Celx:v160}} horizontalgrid }} '''Notes:''' # Multiple features can be enabled at once by giving multiple arguments to this method, separated by a comma. '''Example:'''
Enable the rendering of comet-tails celestia:show("comettails")
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== hide === {{Celx:func|celestia:hide}}({{Celx:arg|string:renderflag}}) Disable one or many rendering features. This method exists for backward compatibility with older scripts. The [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setrenderflags|celestia:setrenderflags()]] method should be used instead. {{Celx:argdesc| ;renderflag: String describing the render-feature to be disabled. :* See the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#show|celestia:show()]] method. }} '''Notes:''' # Multiple features can be enabled at once by giving multiple arguments to this method, separated by a comma. '''Example:'''
Disable the rendering of nightmaps celestia:hide("nightmaps")
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== getrenderflags === table {{Celx:func|celestia:getrenderflags()}} Return a table with all known renderflags (see [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setrenderflags|celestia:setrenderflags()]] method) as keys, and a boolean as value indicating whether a specific renderflag is enabled or disabled. '''Notes:''' # This method is especially useful to save all renderflags at the beginning of a script, so these values can be reset at script end or script termination, by using the function '''celestia_cleanup_callback()'''. '''Example:''' actual_renderflags = celestia:getrenderflags()
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== setrenderflags === {{Celx:func|celestia:setrenderflags}}({{Celx:arg|table:renderflags}}) You can use [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#show|celestia:show]] and [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#hide|celestia:hide]] or this '''celestia:setrenderflags()''' method, both have equivalent functionality. The main reason for the existence of this method is as a counterpart of the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#getrenderflags|celestia:getrenderflags()]] method. {{Celx:argdesc| ;renderflags: A table which contains the renderflags as keys, and booleans as values for each key. Valid renderflag keys are: :* orbits :* cloudmaps :* constellations :* galaxies :* planets :* stars :* nightmaps :* eclipseshadows :* ringshadows :* comettails :* boundaries :* markers :* automag :* atmospheres :* grid :* smoothlines :* lightdelay :* partialtrajectories :* {{Celx:v150}} cloudshadows :* {{Celx:v150}} nebulae :* {{Celx:v150}} openclusters :* {{Celx:v160}} globulars :* {{Celx:v160}} ecliptic :* {{Celx:v160}} equatorialgrid :* {{Celx:v160}} galacticgrid :* {{Celx:v160}} eclipticgrid :* {{Celx:v160}} horizontalgrid }} '''Example:'''
Enable the rendering of comet-tails and disable the rendering of nightmaps -- create and initialize table t = {} t.nightmaps = false t.comettails = true celestia:setrenderflags(t) or shorter: -- note the curly braces celestia:setrenderflags{nightmaps = false, comettails = true}
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== showlabel === {{Celx:v132}} {{Celx:func|celestia:showlabel}}({{Celx:arg|string:labelflag}}) Enable the rendering of labels. {{Celx:argdesc| ;labelflag: String describing the type of labels to enable, must be one of: :* planets :* moons :* spacecraft :* asteroids :* comets :* stars :* galaxies :* locations :* constellations :* {{Celx:v150}} i18nconstellations :** used to display either the Latin or the translated label names of constellations when the labeling of constellations is enabled. :* {{Celx:v150}} openclusters :* {{Celx:v150}} nebulae :* {{Celx:v160}} dwarfplanets :* {{Celx:v160}} minormoons :* {{Celx:v160}} globulars }} '''Notes:''' # Multiple label features can be enabled at once by giving multiple arguments to this method, separated by a comma. '''Example:'''
Enable the labeling of planets and moons celestia:showlabel("planets", "moons")
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== hidelabel === {{Celx:v132}} {{Celx:func|celestia:hidelabel}}({{Celx:arg|string:labelflag}}) Disable the rendering of labels. {{Celx:argdesc| ; labelflag: String describing the type of labels to disable. :* See the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#showlabel|celestia:showlabel()]] method. }} '''Notes:''' # Multiple label features can be disabled at once by giving multiple arguments to this method, separated by a comma. '''Example:'''
Enable the labeling of constellations in local an Latin names respectively celestia:showlabel("constellations") -- Show local translated names for constellations celestia:showlabel("i18nconstellations") wait(5.0) -- Show Latin names for constellations celestia:hidelabel("i18nconstellations") wait(5.0) celestia:hidelabel("constellations")
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== getlabelflags === {{Celx:v132}} table {{Celx:func|celestia:getlabelflags()}} Return a table with all known labelflags (see [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setlabelflags|celestia:setlabelflags()]] method) as keys, and a boolean as value indicating whether a specific labelflag is enabled or disabled. '''Notes:''' # This method is especially useful to save all labelflags at the beginning of a script, so these values can be reset at script end or script termination, by using the function '''celestia_cleanup_callback()'''. # To enable or disable a specific labelflag, the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setlabelflags|celestia:setlabelflags()]] method can be used. '''Example:''' actual_labelflags = celestia:getlabelflags()
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== setlabelflags === {{Celx:v132}} {{Celx:func|celestia:setlabelflags}}({{Celx:arg|table:labelflags}}) Enable or disable the rendering of labels. You can use [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#showlabel|celestia:showlabel()]] and [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#hidelabel|celestia:hidelabel()]] or this '''celestia:setlabelflags()''' method, both have equivalent functionality. {{Celx:argdesc| ; labelflags: A table which contains the labelflags as keys, and booleans as values for each key. Valid labelflag keys are: :* planets :* moons :* spacecraft :* asteroids :* comets :* stars :* galaxies :* locations :* constellations :* {{Celx:v150}} i18nconstellations :** used to display either the Latin or the translated label names of constellations when the labeling of constellations is enabled. :* {{Celx:v150}} openclusters :* {{Celx:v150}} nebulae :* {{Celx:v160}} dwarfplanets :* {{Celx:v160}} minormoons :* {{Celx:v160}} globulars }} '''Notes:''' # To obtain the current status for the rendering of labels, the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#getlabelflags|celestia:getlabelflags()]] method can be used. '''Example:'''
Enable the labeling of planets and dwarfplanets and disable the labeling of moons -- create and initialize table table = {} table.planets = true table.dwarfplanets = true table.moons = false celestia:setlabelflags(table) or shorter: -- note the curly braces celestia:setlabelflags{planets = true, dwarfplanets = true, moons = false}
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== getorbitflags === {{Celx:v132}} table {{Celx:func|celestia:getorbitflags()}} Return a table with all known orbitflags (see the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setorbitflags|celestia:setorbitflags()]] method) as keys, and a boolean as value, indicating
whether a specific orbit is enabled or disabled, when orbits are turned on using the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setrenderflags|celestia:setrenderflags()]] method. '''Notes:''' # To enable or disable the rendering of specific orbits, the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setorbitflags|celestia:setorbitflags()]] method can be used. '''Example:''' actual_orbitflags = celestia:getorbitflags()
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== setorbitflags === {{Celx:v132}} {{Celx:func|celestia:setorbitflags}}({{Celx:arg|table:orbitflags}}) Enable or disable the rendering of specific orbits, when orbits are turned on using the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setrenderflags|celestia:setrenderflags()]] method. {{Celx:argdesc| ; orbitflags: :A table which contains the orbitflags as keys, and booleans as values for each key. :Each orbitflag must be one of: :* Planet :* Moon :* Asteroid :* Comet :* Spacecraft :* Invisible :* Unknown :* {{Celx:v160}} DwarfPlanet :* {{Celx:v160}} MinorMoon :* {{Celx:v160}} Star :'''Note''': Mind the case sensitivity of celestia, regarding the keys for this celestia method !!! }} '''Notes:''' # To obtain the current status for the rendering of specific orbits, the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#getorbitflags|celestia:getorbitflags()]] method can be used. '''Example:'''
Enable the rendering of the orbits of planets and dwarfplanets only: -- create and initialize table first table = {} table.Planet = true table.Moon = false table.Asteroid = false table.Comet = false table.Spacecraft = false table.Invisible = false table.Unknown = false table.DwarfPlanet = true table.MinorMoon = false table.Star = false celestia:setorbitflags(table) celestia:setrenderflags{orbits = true} or shorter: -- note the curly braces celestia:setorbitflags{Planet = true, Moon = false, Asteroid = false, Comet = false, Spacecraft = false, Invisible = false, Unknown = false, DwarfPlanet = true, MinorMoon = false, Star = false} celestia:setrenderflags{orbits = true}
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== getambient === {{Celx:v132}} number {{Celx:func|celestia:getambient()}} Return the current brightness level of ambient light as a number. '''Notes:''' # To set the brightness level of ambient light, the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setambient|celestia:setambient()]] method can be used. '''Example:''' actual_ambient = celestia:getambient()
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== setambient === {{Celx:v132}} {{Celx:func|celestia:setambient}}({{Celx:arg|number:ambient}}) Set the brightness level of ambient light. {{Celx:argdesc| ;ambient: The new level of ambient light, must be between 0 and 1, otherwise it will be adjusted to the nearest valid value (0 or 1). :* For realism, this number should be set to 0.0. The side of the body facing away from the Sun will be totally dark. :* Setting this number to 1.0 will cause the side of the body facing away from the Sun to appear as bright as the lit side. }} '''Notes:''' # To obtain the current brightness level of ambient light, the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#getambient|celestia:getambient()]] method can be used. '''Example:''' celestia:setambient(0.0)
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== getfaintestvisible === {{Celx:v132}} number {{Celx:func|celestia:getfaintestvisible()}} Return the current faintest visible magnitude of stars as a number. If AutoMag has been enabled (see the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setrenderflags|celestia:setrenderflags()]] method), this method returns the faintest magnitude of stars at 45° instead. '''Notes:''' # To set the faintest visible magnitude of stars or the faintest magnitude of stars at 45°, the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setfaintestvisible|celestia:setfaintestvisible()]] method can be used. '''Example:''' actual_faintest = celestia:getfaintestvisible()
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== setfaintestvisible === {{Celx:v132}} {{Celx:func|celestia:setfaintestvisible}}({{Celx:arg|number:faintest}}) Set the faintest visible magnitude of stars. If AutoMag has been enabled (see the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setrenderflags|celestia:setrenderflags()]] method), set the faintest magnitude of stars at 45° instead. {{Celx:argdesc| ; faintest: The new faintest visible magnitude of stars. : The Celestia user interface allows a range from about 1.0 to 15.0. }} '''Notes:''' # When Galaxies are turned on, using the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setrenderflags|celestia:setrenderflags()]] method, Galaxy brightness will also respond to setting the faintest visible magnitude of stars, using this '''celestia:setfaintestvisible()''' method. This method is linked with the {{Celx:v150}} [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setgalaxylightgain|celestia:setgalaxylightgain()]] method. # To obtain the current faintest visible magnitude of stars or the current faintest magnitude of stars at 45°, the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#getfaintestvisible|celestia:getfaintestvisible()]] method can be used. '''Example-1:'''
Set the faintest maginute of stars at 45° to 9.0 celestia:setrenderflags{automag = true} celestia:setfaintestvisible(9.0) '''Example-2:'''
Set the faintest visible magnitude of stars to 7.0 celestia:setrenderflags{automag = false} celestia:setfaintestvisible(7.0)
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== getminorbitsize === {{Celx:v132}} number {{Celx:func|celestia:getminorbitsize()}} Return the current minimum size for an orbit to be rendered, as a number. This value is used when Celestia's '''orbits''' renderflag option is turned on, using the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setrenderflags|celestia:setrenderflags()]] method.
The size is measured in pixels and is related to the radius of the orbit. '''Notes:''' # The actual screen dimensions in pixels can be obtained using the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#getscreendimension|celestia:getscreendimension()]] method. # To set minimum size for an orbit to be rendered, the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setminorbitsize|celestia:setminorbitsize()]] method can be used. '''Example:''' actual_orbitsize = celestia:getminorbitsize()
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== setminorbitsize === {{Celx:v132}} {{Celx:func|celestia:setminorbitsize}}({{Celx:arg|number:orbitsize}}) Set the minimum size of an orbit to be rendered. This value is used when Celestia's '''orbits''' renderflag option is turned on, using the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setrenderflags|celestia:setrenderflags()]] method. {{Celx:argdesc| ; orbitsize: The minimum size of an orbit to be rendered. : A negative orbitsize value is considered to be zero. : The size is measured in pixels and is related to the radius of the orbit. :* '''Note''': When the size is greater than 50% of the screen dimensions, no orbits will be rendered at all. }} '''Notes:''' # Using this method, you can for instance influence the moment to fade out the inner orbits of planets, when zooming out of a Solar System (or vice versa, to fade in when zooming in on a Solar System). # Screen dimensions can differ on different computers, so can be the effect of this method. # To obtain the current minimum size for an orbit to be rendered, the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#getminorbitsize|celestia:getminorbitsize()]] method can be used. '''Example:'''
Set the minimum radius size of an orbit to be rendered at 30 pixels and render the orbits of planets celestia:setrenderflags{orbits = true} celestia:setorbitflags{Planet = true} celestia:setminorbitsize(30)
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== getstardistancelimit === {{Celx:v132}} number {{Celx:func|celestia:getstardistancelimit()}} Return the furthest distance, measured in light years, at which Celestia will display stars, as a number. The default value is 1,000,000, however, as of version 1.3.1, Celestia only uses a distance out to 16,000 light years. '''Notes:''' # To set the furthest distance at which Celestia will display stars, the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setstardistancelimit|celestia:setstardistancelimit()]] method can be used. '''Example:''' actual_stardistancelimit = celestia:getstardistancelimit()
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== setstardistancelimit === {{Celx:v132}} {{Celx:func|celestia:setstardistancelimit}}({{Celx:arg|number:distance}}) Set the furthest distance at which Celestia will display stars. {{Celx:argdesc| ; distance: The maximum star distance in light years at which Celestia will display stars. }} '''Notes:''' # To obtain the current furthest distance at which Celestia will display stars, the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#getstardistancelimit|celestia:getstardistancelimit()]] method can be used. '''Example:'''
only show stars which are less than 100 ly away celestia:setstardistancelimit(100)
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== getminfeaturesize === {{Celx:v132}} number {{Celx:func|celestia:getminfeaturesize()}} Return the minimum size for locations to be labeled. This value is used when Celestia's '''locations''' labelflag option is turned on, using the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setlabelflags|celestia:setlabelflags()]] or [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#showlabel|celestia:showlabel()]] method. '''Notes:''' # When observing a planet or moon from far away, the largest or important locations are shown first from a certain distance. As you approach the planet or moon, more location labels will appear. # The sizes of defined locations are determined in the locations files that are stored within the Celestia subdirectories. Locations with a defined size less than the minimum size for locations, will '''not''' be labeled. # The [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setminfeaturesize|celestia:setminfeaturesize()]] method can be used to set the minimum size for locations to be labeled. # The [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx observer#getlocationflags|observer:getlocationflags()]] can be used to obtain a table with keys that indicate whether a specific locationflag is enabled or disabled. '''Example:''' actual_minfeaturesize = celestia:getminfeaturesize()
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== setminfeaturesize === {{Celx:v132}} {{Celx:func|celestia:setminfeaturesize}}({{Celx:arg|number:size}}) Set the minimum size for locations to be labeled. This value is used when Celestia's '''locations''' labelflag option is turned on, using the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setlabelflags|celestia:setlabelflags()]] or [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#showlabel|celestia:showlabel()]] method. {{Celx:argdesc| ; size: The minimum feature size for locations to be labeled. : A negative size value is considered to be zero. : Locations with a defined size of less than this size will '''not''' be labeled. }} '''Notes:''' # When observing a planet or moon from far away, the largest or important locations are shown first from a certain distance. As you approach the planet or moon, more location labels will appear. # The sizes of defined locations are determined in the locations files that are stored within the Celestia subdirectories. # The [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#getminfeaturesize|celestia:getminfeaturesize()]] method can be used to obtain the current minimum size for locations to be labeled. # The [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx observer#setlocationflags|observer:setlocationflags()]] can be used to determine whether a specific locationflag is enabled or disabled. '''Example:'''
Set the minimum featuresize to 1, to display all available location labels celestia:setlabelflags{locations = true} celestia:setminfeaturesize(1)
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== getstarstyle === {{Celx:v132}} string {{Celx:func|celestia:getstarstyle()}} Return the current rendering style for stars as a string. The string will be one of: * '''disc'''
Celestia draws a prominent circular disc that varies in both diameter and brightness, based upon the actual size, magnitude and distance of the star. * '''fuzzy'''
Celestia draws a smaller, more realistic “point” that varies in size and brightness. * '''point'''
Celestia draws stars as points of light of varying brightness. '''Notes:''' # The [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setstarstyle|celestia:setstarstyle()]] method can be used to set the rendering style for stars. '''Example:''' actual_starstyle = celestia:getstarstyle()
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== setstarstyle === {{Celx:v132}} {{Celx:func|celestia:setstarstyle}}({{Celx:arg|string:starstyle}}) Set the rendering style for stars. {{Celx:argdesc| ;starstyle: The new rendering style for stars. : Must be one of: :* '''disc'''
Celestia draws a prominent circular disc that varies in both diameter and brightness, based upon the actual size, magnitude and distance of the star. :* '''fuzzy'''
Celestia draws a smaller, more realistic “point” that varies in size and brightness. :* '''point'''
Celestia draws stars as points of light of varying brightness. }} '''Notes:''' # The [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#getstarstyle|celestia:getstarstyle()]] method can be used to obtain the current rendering style for stars. '''Example:'''
The uncommented line sets the starstyle -- celestia:setstarstyle("disc") -- celestia:setstarstyle("fuzzy") celestia:setstarstyle("point")
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== find === object {{Celx:func|celestia:find}}({{Celx:arg|string:name}}) This celestia method can be used to create a CELX "object" object. {{Celx:argdesc| ; name: String describing the wanted planet, moon, asteroid, comet, galaxy, spacecraft, etc. :* Stars and space objects are named by their common names or Bayer and Flamsteed designations and HD or HIP catalog numbers
(e.g. "Polaris", "HIP 21589", "41 ari"). :*Galaxies are named by their common names or through their Messier numbers, NGC, UGC or MCG catalog numbers
(e.g. "M 33", "Milky way"). :*Planets, moons, asteroids and artificial satellites may be named by their common names
(e.g. "Mir", "Jupiter", "Io", "Cassini") : '''Note:''' If you are currently positioned outside of our solar system, and want to seek an object inside of our solar system,
you must include "Sol/" in the name string (e.g. "Sol/Mars"). : '''Note:''' If you are seeking a named Location on a planet or moon, you must include the name of the planet or moon where the location is found,
as well as the location itself, separated by a slash / mark (e.g. "Earth/Amsterdam" or "Sol/Earth/Amsterdam"). }} '''Notes:''' # A CELX "object" object does refer to a celestial object like a planet or a star, but it can also be a location or spacecraft. # The [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx object|object]] methods can be used on a CELX "object" object. "Object" objects can also be used in other methods, requiring an "object" object as an argument. '''Example:''' -- Find Earth and store in object with name "planet_earth", when in our Solar System planet_earth = celestia:find("Earth") -- Find Earth and store in object with name "planet_earth", when outside of our Solar System planet_earth = celestia:find("Sol/Earth") -- Find Galaxy M33 and store in object with name "galaxy_m33" galaxy_m33 = celestia:find("M 33") -- Find Jupiter's moon Callisto and store in object with name "callisto" callisto = celestia:find("Sol/Jupiter/Callisto")
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== getselection === object {{Celx:func|celestia:getselection()}} Return the current selection in a CELX "object" object. '''Notes:''' # A CELX "object" object does refer to a celestial object like a planet or a star, but it can also be a location or spacecraft. # The [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx object|object]] methods can be used on a CELX "object" object. "Object" objects can also be used in other methods, requiring an "object" object as an argument. '''Example:'''
Get the current selection. If nothing is selected, the Sun will be selected actual_selection = celestia:getselection() if actual_selection:type() == "null" then actual_selection = celestia:find("Sol") celestia:select(actual_selection) end
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== select === {{Celx:func|celestia:select}}({{Celx:arg|object:obj}}) Set the current selection to the specified object. {{Celx:argdesc| ;obj: The object which will be the new selection. : If not a valid object, the selection will be cleared. }} '''Example:'''
Find and select our Moon moon = celestia:find("Sol/Earth/Moon") celestia:select(moon) Or shorter celestia:select(celestia:find("Sol/Earth/Moon"))
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== mark === {{Celx:func|celestia:mark}}({{Celx:arg|object:obj}}) Mark the specified object. {{Celx:argdesc| ; obj: The object to be marked. }} '''Notes:''' # You may want to use the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx object#mark|object:mark()]] method instead, because it has more possibilities. # Markers are only shown when Celestia's '''markers''' renderflag option is turned on, using the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setrenderflags|celestia:setrenderflags()]] method. '''Example:'''
Find, center end mark star Aldebaran selection = celestia:find("Aldebaran") celestia:getobserver():center(selection) celestia:setrenderflags{markers = true} celestia:mark(selection)
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== unmark === {{Celx:func|celestia:unmark}}({{Celx:arg|object:obj}}) Remove marker from the specified object. {{Celx:argdesc| ; obj: The object whose marker should be removed. }} '''Notes:''' # If you don't unmark objects and turn the '''markers''' renderflag off, using the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setrenderflags|celestia:setrenderflags()]] method, Celestia still remembers the marked objects. Next time turning the '''markers''' renderflag on, all the objects will be marked again. # You may want to use the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx object#unmark|object:unmark()]] method instead. '''Example:'''
Find, center end mark star Polaris with a blinking marker for 10 seconds selection = celestia:find("Polaris") celestia:getobserver():center(selection) celestia:setrenderflags{markers = true} for i = 1, 10 do celestia:mark(selection) wait(0.5) celestia:unmark(selection) wait(0.5) end celestia:setrenderflags{markers = false}
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== unmarkall === {{Celx:func|celestia:unmarkall()}} This celestia method removes any previously assigned marks from '''all''' objects. Using this method prevents unmarking all previuosly marked objects individually. '''Notes:''' # If you don't unmark objects and turn the '''markers''' renderflag off, using the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#setrenderflags|celestia:setrenderflags()]] method, Celestia still remembers the marked objects. Next time turning the '''markers''' renderflag on, all the objects will be marked again. '''Example:'''
Find, center end mark stars Pollux and Castor and unmark them again after 5 seconds pollux = celestia:find("Pollux") castor = celestia:find("Castor") celestia:getobserver():center(pollux) celestia:setrenderflags{markers = true} celestia:mark(pollux) celestia:mark(castor) wait(5) celestia:unmarkall() celestia:setrenderflags{markers = false}
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== gettime === number {{Celx:func|celestia:gettime()}} Get the current simulation time as a TDB (''Barycentric Dynamical Time'') Julian date. Older Celestia versions use UTC (''Coordinated Universal Time'') to calculate times and positions.
Starting with version {{Celx:v150}}, although Celestia still displays UTC on the screen,
it uses the TDB time scale internally for everything else, so for CELX scripting !!! '''Notes:''' # The simulation time can be set by using the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#settime|celestia:settime()]] method. # To get the current system time instead of the current simulation time, the {{Celx:v160}} [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#getsystemtime|celestia:getsystemtime()]] method should be used instead. # The TDB time scale is a bit different from the more familiar UTC. By using TDB, Celestia places objects much more accurately. As of January 1, 2008, the difference between the two is about 65 seconds. For more information, see [[Celestia/Time_Scales]]. # To convert between UTC and TDB times, you can use the {{Celx:v150}} [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#utctotdb|celestia:utctotdb()]] and {{Celx:v150}} [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#tdbtoutc|celestia:tdbtoutc()]] methods. # To convert between normal calender dates and julian days, you can use the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#tojulianday|celestia:tojulianday()]] and [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#fromjulianday|celestia:fromjulianday()]] methods. '''Example:''' actual_tdbtime = celestia:gettime()
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== settime === {{Celx:func|celestia:settime}}({{Celx:arg|number:time}}) Set the time for the simulation as a TDB (''Barycentric Dynamical Time'') Julian date. Older Celestia versions use UTC (''Coordinated Universal Time'') to calculate times and positions.
Starting with version {{Celx:v150}}, although Celestia still displays UTC on the screen,
it uses the TDB time scale internally for everything else, so for CELX scripting !!! {{Celx:argdesc| ; time: Number giving the time as a TDB Julian date.
Celestia versions prior to version {{Celx:v150}} use the UTC Julian date number. }} '''Notes:''' # The current simulation time can be obtained by using the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#gettime|celestia:gettime()]] or [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx observer#gettime|observer:gettime()]] method. # The TDB time scale is a bit different from the more familiar UTC. By using TDB, Celestia places objects much more accurately. As of January 1, 2008, the difference between the two is about 65 seconds. For more information, see [[Celestia/Time_Scales]]. # To convert between UTC and TDB times, you can use the {{Celx:v150}} [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#utctotdb|celestia:utctotdb()]] and {{Celx:v150}} [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#tdbtoutc|celestia:tdbtoutc()]] methods. # To convert between normal calender dates and julian days, you can use the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#tojulianday|celestia:tojulianday()]] and [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#fromjulianday|celestia:fromjulianday()]] methods. '''Example:'''
Set the date and time exactly to UTC: October 6, 2009, 19 hr 15 min 30 sec tdb_dt = celestia:utctotdb(2009, 10, 06, 19, 15, 30) celestia:settime(tdb_dt)
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== gettimescale === number {{Celx:func|celestia:gettimescale()}} Get the current multiplier (speed) at which time changes, i.e. how many seconds of simulation time equal one second of real time, as a number. '''Notes:''' # The multiplier (speed) at which time changes can be set by using the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#settimescale|celestia:settimescale()]] method. '''Example:''' actual_timespeed = celestia:gettimescale()
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== settimescale === {{Celx:func|celestia:settimescale}}({{Celx:arg|number:timescale}}) Set the multiplier (speed) at which time changes, i.e. how many seconds of simulation time equal one second of real time. {{Celx:argdesc| ; timescale: The new timespeed. : Defines the time multiplier (i.e. 100x). : Special values are: :* 0: Pause time :* 1: Reset to Real Time :* Negative values reverse time}} '''Notes:''' # The current multiplier (speed) at which time changes can be obtained by using the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#gettimescale|celestia:gettimescale()]] method. '''Example:'''
Set the time multiplier to "1000x faster" celestia:settimescale(1000)
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== getscripttime === number {{Celx:func|celestia:getscripttime()}} Return the elapsed time in seconds (with fractions) since the script has been started, as a number. '''Notes:''' # This method can be useful for timing purposes. '''Example:'''
Print the elapsed script time on the screen. -- Note: The elapsed time in this example increments with a bit more -- than 1 second (as defined in the wait(1.0)). This beacause -- the CELX methods themselves also take time to process. for i = 1, 20 do actual_scripttime = celestia:getscripttime() celestia:print("Elapsed script time: " .. actual_scripttime, 1.0, -1, -1, 2, 4) wait(1.0) end
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== getobserver === observer {{Celx:func|celestia:getobserver()}} Return the current active observer instance in a CELX "observer" object. A CELX "observer" object is used to access properties specific to a view, such as viewer position, viewer orientation, frame of reference, and tracking status. The [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx observer|observer]] methods can be used on a CELX "observer" object. "Observer" objects can also be used in other methods, requiring an "observer" object as an argument. '''Notes:''' # This method returns the observer of the '''active''' view, which can be changed by the user in case of a multiview, using the {{Celx:v160}} [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx observer#makeactiveview|observer:makeactiveview()]] method. '''Example:'''
Get observer instance of the active view and store in obs. obs = celestia:getobserver()
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== getobservers === {{Celx:v132}} table {{Celx:func|celestia:getobservers()}} Return a list of all used observers, i.e. one observer instance for each view in case of a multiview, in a CELX table of "observer" objects. A CELX "observer" object is used to access properties specific to a view, such as viewer position, viewer orientation, frame of reference, and tracking status. The [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx observer|observer]] methods can be used on a CELX "observer" object. "Observer" objects can also be used in other methods, requiring an "observer" object as an argument. '''Notes:''' # Each time you change the number of observer instances with the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx observer#splitview|observer:splitview()]] or [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx observer#deleteview|observer:deleteview()]] methods in a multiview, you need to update the table of "observer" objects again with this '''celestia:getobservers()''' method. '''Example:'''
Split the actual view in the middle vertically. Left goto Venus, right goto Mars and restore singleview after 10 seconds again. obs = celestia:getobserver() obs:splitview("V", 0.5) observers = celestia:getobservers() venus = celestia:find("Sol/Venus") observers[1]:goto(venus) mars = celestia:find("Sol/Mars") observers[2]:goto(mars) wait(10.0) obs:singleview()
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== tojulianday === number {{Celx:func|celestia:tojulianday}}({{Celx:arg|number:year [, number:month, number:day, number:hour, number:minute, number:seconds]}}) Convert a UTC calendar date/time to a UTC Julian date and return this Julian date as a number. The UTC Julian date is the interval of time in days and fractions of a day since January 1, 4712 BC Greenwich noon (12:00:00). {{Celx:argdesc| ; year: Integer value for the year of this date ; month [optional]: Integer value (1 - 12) for the month within the year of this date. Default is 1. ; day [optional]: Integer value (1 - 31) for the day within the month of this date. Default is 1. ; hour[optional]: Integer value for the hour within the day of this date. Default is 0. ; minute [optional]: Integer value for the minute within the hour of this date. Default is 0. ; seconds [optional]: Float value for the seconds within the minute of this date. Default is 0.0. }} '''Notes:''' # Starting with version {{Celx:v150}}, although Celestia still displays UTC on the screen, it uses the TDB time scale internally for everything else, so for CELX scripting !!! For these newer Celestia versions, using the UTC Julian date (as a result of this '''celestia:tojulianday()''' method) in the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#settime|celestia:settime()]] method, will cause the '''WRONG''' setting of the simutation time. To set the simulation time, using Julian date for these newer Celestia versions, the {{Celx:v150}} [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#utctotdb|celestia:utctotdb()]] method should be used instead of this '''celestia:tojulianday()''' method. # For more information on TDB, UTC, and how time is used in Celestia, see [[Celestia/Time Scales]]. '''Example-1:'''
Using a later version of Celestia than version {{Celx:v150}}, this example-1 will set the '''WRONG''' simulation time, which can be checked by reading out the date time in the upper right corner off your screen after running this example-1 script. This example-1 only works correct for Celestia versions '''prior''' to version {{Celx:v150}}. utc_juliandate = celestia:tojulianday(2009, 10, 06, 12, 00, 0.0) celestia:settime(utc_juliandate) celestia:settimescale(0) '''Example-2:'''
Using a later version of Celestia than version {{Celx:v150}}, the next example-2 will set the '''RIGHT''' simulation time, which can be checked by reading out the date time in the upper right corner off your screen after running this example-2 script. tdb_juliandate = celestia:utctotdb(2009, 10, 06, 12, 00, 0.0) celestia:settime(tdb_juliandate) celestia:settimescale(0)
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== fromjulianday === {{Celx:v132}} table {{Celx:func|celestia:fromjulianday}}({{Celx:arg|number:jd}}) Convert a UTC Julian date to a UTC calendar date/time. The returned table contains the keys: * year * month * day * hour * minute * seconds The UTC Julian date is the interval of time in days and fractions of a day since January 1, 4712 BC Greenwich noon (12:00:00). {{Celx:argdesc| ;jd: The UTC Julian date number. : Special values: :* 0 is the day at the above-mentioned reference date :* Negative values can be used for preceding dates :*The Julian day number (JDN) is the integral part of the Julian date (JD). :** The Julian day number of January 1, 2010 is 2455198. :* The decimal parts of a Julian date: :** 0.1 is 2.4 hours or 144 minutes or 8640 seconds :** 0.01 is 0.24 hours or 14.4 minutes or 864 seconds :** 0.001 is 0.024 hours or 1.44 minutes or 86.4 seconds :** 0.0001 is 0.0024 hours or 0.144 minutes or 8.64 seconds :** 0.00001 is 0.00024 hours or 0.0144 minutes or 0.864 seconds. }} '''Notes:''' # Starting with version {{Celx:v150}}, although Celestia still displays UTC on the screen, it uses the TDB time scale internally for everything else, so for CELX scripting !!! For these newer Celestia versions, using the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#gettime|celestia:gettime()]] method to obtain a Julian date, and convert that to a Calender date/time with this '''celestia:fromjulianday()''' method, will cause to obtain the '''WRONG''' Calender date/time. To obtain the right Calender date/time, using the Julian date from the [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#gettime|celestia:gettime()]] method, for these newer Celestia versions, the {{Celx:v150}} [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx celestia#tdbtoutc|celestia:tdbtoutc()]] method should be used instead. # For more information on TDB, UTC, and how time is used in Celestia, see [[Celestia/Time Scales]]. '''Example-1:'''
Using a later version of Celestia than version {{Celx:v150}}, this example-1 will obtain the '''WRONG''' TDB Calender date/time, instead of the mentioned UTC Calender date/time. This can be checked by comparing the result of the print statement with the UTC date/time displayed in the upper right corner of your screen. This example-1 only works correct for Celestia versions '''prior''' to version {{Celx:v150}}. celestia:settimescale(0) utc_juliandate = celestia:gettime() ut = celestia:fromjulianday(utc_juliandate) celestia:print("Date/time: " .. ut.year .. " " .. ut.month .. " " .. ut.day .. " " .. ut.hour .. " " .. ut.minute .. " " .. ut.seconds, 10.0, -1, -1, 2, 4) wait(10.0) '''Example-2:'''
Using a later version of Celestia than version {{Celx:v150}}, the next example-2 will set the '''RIGHT''' UTC Calender date/time. This can be checked by comparing the result of the print statement with the UTC date/time displayed in the upper right corner of your screen. celestia:settimescale(0) tdb_juliandate = celestia:gettime() ut = celestia:tdbtoutc(tdb_juliandate) celestia:print("Date/time: " .. ut.year .. " " .. ut.month .. " " .. ut.day .. " " .. ut.hour .. " " .. ut.minute .. " " .. ut.seconds, 10.0, -1, -1, 2, 4) wait(10.0)
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== getscreendimension === {{Celx:v132}} x, y {{Celx:func|celestia:getscreendimension()}} Return the width (=x) and height (=y) of the current Celestia window in pixels, as 2 numbers. '''Example:''' x,y = celestia:getscreendimension() celestia:print("Width: " .. x .. " pixels.\nHeight: " .. y .. " pixels.", 10.0, -1, -1, 4, 4) wait (10.0)
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== newvector === vector {{Celx:func|celestia:newvector}}({{Celx:arg|number:x, number:y, number:z}}) This celestia method can be used to create a new CELX "vector" object from numbers. {{Celx:argdesc| ;x: The X-component of the new vector, as a number in millionths of a light year. ;y: The Y-component of the new vector, as a number in millionths of a light year. ;z: The Z-component of the new vector, as a number in millionths of a light year. }} '''Notes:''' # When you have vector components defined in km or miles, you first have to convert those components to millionths of a light year.
Therefore, you can use a constant, which must be initialized first within your script: #* From km to millionths of a light year, use a constant uly_to_km = 9460730.4725808. #* From miles to millionths of a light year, use a constant uly_to_mls = 5912956.5453630. # Next you can convert km or miles to millionths of a light year as follows: #* millionths_of_a_light_year = ''number:km'' / uly_to_km #* millionths_of_a_light_year = ''number:miles'' / uly_to_mls # A CELX "vector" object is a geometric object that has both a length and direction [X, Y, Z] in a 3 dimensional coordinate system. # The [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx vector|vector]] methods can be used on a CELX "vector" object. "Vector" objects can also be used in other methods, requiring a "vector" object as an argument. '''Example-1:'''
Make a vector, pointing in the Y-direction with length 1. up_vector = celestia:newvector(0, 1, 0) '''Example-2:'''
Make a vector, pointing in the X-direction with length 5000 km. uly_to_km = 9460730.4725808 x5k_vector = celestia:newvector(5000/uly_to_km, 0, 0)
[[Celestia/Celx_Scripting/CELX_Lua_Methods#celestia|Return to the '''celestia''' method index.]]


=== newposition === {{Celx:v132}} position {{Celx:func|celestia:newposition}}({{Celx:arg|number:x, number:y, number:z}}) This celestia method can be used to create a new CELX "position" object from numbers. {{Celx:argdesc| ;x: The X-component of the new position, as a number in millionths of a light year. ;y: The Y-component of the new position, as a number in millionths of a light year. ;z: The Z-component of the new position, as a number in millionths of a light year. }} '''Notes:''' # When you have position components defined in km or miles, you first have to convert those components to millionths of a light year.
Therefore, you can use a constant, which must be initialized first within your script: #* From km to millionths of a light year, use a constant uly_to_km = 9460730.4725808. #* From miles to millionths of a light year, use a constant uly_to_mls = 5912956.5453630. # Next you can convert km or miles to millionths of a light year as follows: #* millionths_of_a_light_year = ''number:km'' / uly_to_km #* millionths_of_a_light_year = ''number:miles'' / uly_to_mls # A CELX "position" object contains the exact coordinates of a point in space. A position is relative to a coordinate system and may need to be converted to or from universal coordinates before further use. # The [[Celestia/Celx Scripting/CELX Lua Methods/Celx position|position]] methods can be used on a CELX "position" object. "Position" objects can also be used in other methods, requiring a "position" object as an argument. '''Example:'''
